PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating Government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.TITLE: Mining and Export of Uranium

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patents
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate. The undersigned citizens of Australia, and custodians of the Earth, oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would *reduce biodiversity, *compromise animal welfare, *concentrate ownership of breeding stock, and *allow companies to appropriate the fruit of centuries of selective breeding. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Officer and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more;
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We pray that all members of the Australian Senate will act on this petition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Senate Estimates Committee D it emerged that the divisional returning officers apparently do not provide information to the Electoral Commissioner about the extent to which the electoral rolls are demonstrated to be unsatisfactory as a result of the return-`not known at this address' and so on-of letters sent out by senators and members to their constituents. —They just don't want to know you.

—I take the point that the Government Deputy Whip makes, that they do not want to acknowledge receipt of a letter with the crest of the Senate on it. He claimed that he had received no complaints whatsoever about the nature of the rolls from anyone, as I recall. Perhaps I am being unfair to him. SPEECH.PARA: Many members and senators not only write `welcome to the electorate' letters but they also direct mail. They send direct mail to large sections of the electorate, or to the total electorate. Many Labor members of the House of Representatives used an illegal allowance provided by this Government, which they ought to repay. It cost $30,000 a member, and now the taxpayer is being made, illegally, to carry that cost.

Many members like me, who at their own expense sent direct mail to sections of the electorate, found a grossly unsatisfactory failure rate of letters being returned with the words `Not known at this address'. But what I am really concerned about is the failure of the Commissioner to recognise or to have been informed that senators and members are returning these failed envelopes to the divisional returning officer (DRO). This suggests to me that there is a lack of concern and a lack of willingness to take action on this matter, emerging in effect from a lack of knowledge.

I do not know whether members of the House of Representatives have the view that they should advise their divisional returning officer of the number of failed letters. I hope they do but it would seem to me that we could perhaps encourage the Government, as it clearly has an enthusiastic support for the concept of people writing to their constituents-even illegally, by providing them with illegal stamp allowances-to show the same enthusiasm in encouraging senators and members to return the failed envelopes to the DRO and also to encourage the divisional returning officers to make certain that the hierarchy in the Electoral Commission is aware of this failure rate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bottom line of my response is that Senator Michael Baume should not presume that, because no-one is there to answer when he knocks on the door or people do not respond to his correspondence, they are not there at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume should take into account that, in respect of the last election in particular, a full-scale electoral roll review was conducted in 1989. That is one particular and comprehensive way of checking the accuracy of the electoral roll. A second way is to keep a continual monitoring of Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) generated mail returned to sender. Of course, that is an important mechanism. A third way is failure to vote, and that is always followed up.

However-and this is where I think Senator Baume might have been a bit unfair to the Electoral Commissioner, and from where I was last week at the Estimates Committee hearings I also had difficulty in understanding the direct purport of Senator Baume's questions-the Electoral Commission advises that confirmation of an elector's eligibility to remain on the roll is sought when members or senators advise that welcome-to-the-electorate letters have been returned, they being letters that politicians send out to people who they have been notified have moved into the electorate. When members or senators advise that those letters are returned the AEC responds to that particular problem. However, returned mail from members' or senators' mailings to all electors in a division does not automatically generate follow-up by the AEC.

Essentially, when people register as moving into the electorate and correspondence to them from members or senators is returned and those members or senators advise the Electoral Commission, that is followed up. General mailings, however, have particular problems. For instance, the computer tapes provided by the Australian Electoral Commission to, for instance, the Liberal Party in New South Wales were provided, in fact, last year. They were tapes which show electors by residence in September 1989, some six months before the election. Naturally there was some movement between the time of making the tape and the time of the mailing out by members or senators, so we should take into account that perhaps those tapes should not be seen as the most appropriate way for comprehensive checking of whether people are or are not in the electorate.

We are taking further measures. For instance, the AEC is currently undertaking a survey in a sample of divisions of electors enrolled in the period prior to the close of the rolls for the 1990 election. I am informed that, while the investigation is by no means complete, preliminary analysis of a small sample of the data suggests that the return to sender mail is not a totally reliable indication that the elector no longer resides at the enrolled address. For example, the data shows that a significant proportion of returned mail was due to very slight errors in the addresses keyed into the enrolment system. For instance, people may still be in the location that they have indicated but the tape itself may not have total accuracy. It is quite clear also from the surveys that some people object to direct mail from any source. I am one of them. Although still living at the address, they indicate return to sender.

The data also suggest-and I think this is important-that large numbers of electors legitimately on the roll at the close of rolls had moved to a new address within one month of polling date. This highlights the mobility of the population and the need to use the most up-to-date electoral roll information available when directly mailing electors.

Another thing the Government has done-and it is important and perhaps Senator Michael Baume could take it up with his colleagues in New South Wales-is to take a decision that the Electoral Commission be funded to undertake annual roll reviews in those States which are prepared to share equally in the costs of maintaining joint rolls. Such arrangements are in place in South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. We are currently looking at provisions for financial arrangements with other States but, in view of what Senator Michael Baume is concerned about, in view of the State that he represents and in view of the political affinity that he has with the Government, it could be useful if he were to put in a good word with the New South Wales Government for it to undertake the commitment that some other States are undertaking.

In summary, the Australian Electoral Commission is consistently and comprehensively addressing this particular issue. I think, as I made the point just a little while earlier, Senator Baume's questions were a bit difficult to decipher on the night and I think the attack on the Electoral Commissioner is unfair.

As a senator for New South Wales I would certainly be only too keen to discuss the matter with my State colleagues to see the extent to which action can be taken to ensure that the best possible rolls are available for both State and Federal elections. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —At long last it has sunk through to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus). Even though I read the question I asked at the Senate Estimates Committee, only by way of interjection from me has the Minister at last comprehended what I asked about. SPEECH.PARA: Do divisional returning officers indicate up the management chain the sort of failure rate . . . In things like welcoming new people to the electorate . . .

The Minister's response just now was that it is managed at divisional returning officer level. That was not the point of the question. If it does not do it with acknowledgment cards, can it smarten up its act?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the divisional returning officer is in fact the registrar of the roll. There is not in the ordinary way a managerial mechanism to provide information up the system. The registrar of the roll is the divisional returning officer who has responsibility for checking the roll and keeping it in appropriate order.

SPEECH.PARA: It is anticipated that if there were an exceptional problem it would be raised in the consultative way in which the Electoral Commission works, but further advice is that there has not been a need for that to happen. Essentially, going back to the initial point, this particular question of keeping the roll up to date is conducted at a divisional level.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the Minister-he was much clearer this time-it is only if there were an exceptional problem that the divisional returning officer would advise up the chain of any failure rate or so on. Does the Electoral Commissioner provide any guidelines for divisional returning officers about what is an exceptional problem and what is an unexceptional problem?
—No.

—It is evident that there is no point in proceeding further with this matter. The failure of the Government to take effective and appropriate action to ensure that the rolls are as clean as they should be no doubt goes quite some way to explaining how this party, the Australian Labor Party, is in government with a minority of votes right now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to that. I have taken enough personal abuse from Senator Baume this morning and, in responding to it, I have restrained myself as much as I can. I think that last implication is outrageous and it is one without basis. We have had a grubby little performance here this morning from Senator Baume, who made certain implications and allegations.

—I will cover what I have to say by referring anyone who may be listening to this debate or who may want to read the debate in the Hansard to the comments I made at the outset of this debate. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You are getting very wide of the issue, Senator Bolkus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to seek a little clarification from the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) because it is thoroughly confusing as to what on earth the Electoral Commissioner does with the information that Senator Baume referred to. It would seem to me that by returning those envelopes we are assisting the Electoral Commission in its efforts to cleanse the rolls. I want to know whether we are wasting our time returning those envelopes to the divisional returning officer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer this question and perhaps satisfy Senator Teague if he has a question concerning the same matter. I said that confirmation of an elector's eligibility to remain on the roll is sought when members or senators advise the Electoral Commission that welcome to the electorate letters have been returned. What happens in terms of the matter being `taken up' is that, if the Australian Electoral Commission is advised by members or senators or anyone else that welcome to the electorate letters have been returned, the Electoral Commission writes to the person concerned indicating that he or she will be taken off the roll unless that person responds to the Electoral Commission. I am informed that, if there is no response within 21 days, that person is taken off the roll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was present when the original questions concerning this matter were raised at the Estimates Committee hearing. I will make a suggestion to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) and to the Australian Electoral Commission resulting from my own experience. Over many years I have received, on a monthly basis, labels of new enrollees from one or two electorates in South Australia and I understand that other senators receive one or two such sets of labels on a monthly basis, as do parties. A division of the Electoral Commission sends to about three or four persons-the member for the electorate, a senator interested in that electorate and at least two major parties-such a set of labels of new enrollees, on a monthly basis. That is all well and good. However, we do not receive a computer print-out of corrections made to the electoral roll on a monthly basis. It would go a long way to solving all the questions that have been raised regarding this matter if, in addition to the labels that we are sent in the way that I have outlined, the divisional office of the Electoral Commission included with the package of labels a computer print-out listing deletions from the electoral roll of which perhaps there would be 500 entries, and corrections to the electoral roll of which perhaps there would be 100 or 50 entries, on a monthly basis. Over the seven or eight years that I have been a senator, I have received about 1,000 new enrollees per month, per electorate, and I think that there would be at least 500 deletions and perhaps 50 corrections per month.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that if we received such a computer print-out and if that list were sent to the other persons receiving labels, as I have already outlined, we would be accountable to our electorates. We would be able to engage in a constructive dialogue with the divisional officers of the Electoral Commission and we would be able to check, ourselves, what had happened to those envelopes that we had taken to the Electoral Commission every month or two, which had been returned to us marked `Return to sender' or `Not known at this address'. We would be able to check our information with the list of deletions and corrections that would be clearly notified to us on the computer list.

I acknowledge the Electoral Commission's point that the most sure confirmation of a person's address will be that person's confirmation letter returned to the electoral divisional officers. I acknowledge that there will be some electors who, in the words of the Minister, would put `Return to sender' on some categories of mail. However, if we received such a computer print-out on a monthly basis, everything would be clear. Indeed, such lists could be held at the divisional office of the Electoral Commission so that any interested member of the public could also view them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am forced to get to my feet to comment very briefly on the matters raised by Senator Teague. It might be all very well if one serves an electorate where there is a relatively stable population, but if one is serving an electorate such as Kalgoorlie in Western Australia, for instance, where the population can turn around completely from one election to another, I would dread the thought of the monthly returns that would come from the divisional returning officer informing one of the additions to and deletions from the electoral roll.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the big problems we have as senators serving the people of Australia is coping with the amount of paperwork we have to handle to the moment. If we are going to add further reams and reams of paperwork on top of this, we will be floundering. We will not end up doing the job to which we have been elected. I would certainly not seek that service from the divisional returning officer if it were provided. I want these remarks to go on the Hansard record.

I have also got some concerns about the divisional returning officer of the Electoral Commission taking action on the complaints by senators or members as to whether people have moved or are now no longer at a particular address, or whatever. I do get returns of mail saying people have moved on. One can take action but generally one has to do so through the mailing system. If one is servicing a rural electorate, one runs into difficulties in getting responses. I think the poor old electors are hurt enough at the moment with the amount of unsolicited correspondence that they get coming in.

Are we to add another tier to the process of the divisional returning officers by having them action letters which are sent out by members and senators but returned unopened? Many letters which we send out have our return address and name on them and people automatically recognise them and return them because of their political beliefs. It happens even to me. I said by interjection to Senator Michael Baume that people probably do it to him because they are aware of it. We do have to be careful how much more bureaucratise we load onto the system. We do have to be aware that the people that we really should be concerned with here at the moment are the constituents. We are here to serve them and the electors of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been taking this matter up with the Electoral Commissioner since 1987, and a lot of the replies that I have been getting from him just say that a high degree of mobility is the explanation for the number of envelopes returned, and not electoral fraud. I am not fully convinced that that is the case because if somebody enrols on the roll and then three or four weeks later we find they have moved to another area, it absolutely surprises me that they would go on the roll in that area in one particular electorate in the first place. I cannot understand--
—No.
—Well, it is a heck of a high degree of mobility. Why do people not go on the roll where they are going to be, not where they are just going to move from?

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that concerns me is what has happened during the last election. To give an example, in places such as Nimbin-where nobody really seems to know who lives there and when they live there-it is very easy for people to enrol without actually giving an address at which they will live. Why does the Minister not have more advice given to the electoral commissioners to have roll cleansing and habitation reviews very quickly after an election to find out whether the people who voted from a particular address actually lived at that address. I think if that spot checking was done all around Australia, it would definitely take away a lot of the concern and worry that I have. It would not be hard to do, but in places where the enrolment has changed dramatically, I think it would be one of the answers to the problem.

Until the Minister gives the instructions to the Commissioner or tells the Commissioner to do something about it we will have this concern. I have had it for three years and all the other senators here today are concerned about it. I am not suggesting it just because we want to stir the Minister up-which obviously Senator Michael Baume did at the start of his remarks, quite rightly, to get him moving on this subject-but because the people of Australia do not only want to know that the right thing is being done, but want to see that it is being done. At this stage I think my opinion and the opinion of a lot of people in the community is that electoral fraud is going on; and until it is proved otherwise, that is the way we will think.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

That survey basically goes to those who enrolled in the lead-up to the election but who are not living at that particular address now. Each one of those addresses has been doorknocked in a way that was recommended by the Joint Standing Committee. That survey and its results should, I think, be quite useful in ensuring that the appropriate mechanisms are put in place in future. Essentially what Senator Brownhill has asked to be done has been done in a sample of divisions. In those divisions I am told it is a rather exhaustive job. Doors have been knocked on to ensure that fraud is not occurring.

Senator Teague raised the question of corrections. I am advised that at the time we get the computer labels of additions some States also have available deletions and corrections. The corrections are available as part of the computer tape that would ordinarily come through with the computer tape labels; but deletions are available in some particular States. South Australia and Western Australia are two States where I am informed these deletions are made available. They are made available, and some honourable senators, I am informed, have indicated that they do not really want them. But I think in Senator Teague's case we should take it up and see whether we are both on the same track. If we are, we can rectify it. But if we are not, we can see what the issue is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of matters emerge from this which are not satisfactorily dealt with. I understand the Minister's obvious sensitivity on this matter. As Senator Brownhill outlined, he has behaved in an extraordinarily sensitive way this morning. Whatever the motives for that are, I suppose we can only guess at. In view of the fact that members of the Australian Labor Party in the last election undertook the greatest ever direct mail campaign to--
—How did they do it?

—How did they do it, asks Senator Brownhill. It was financed, of course, by a $30,000 grant handed to them by the Government which was then found to be illegal in the High Court. By the way, as I understand it, this chamber rejected the Government's proposal to validate retrospectively an illegal payment, the purpose of which was to influence the result of an election. We are still waiting, of course, for the Labor members who used that money to repay it to the people to whom it belongs-the taxpayers of Australia.
—Do not hold your breath, my friend.

—I am not holding my breath for that illegal payment to be repaid, but I suppose if it depends on morality, we certainly will not expect it to be repaid. The point is that the Labor Party was involved in this enormous direct mail campaign. I am wondering whether all Labor members at least gave the Electoral Commission some benefit for the $30,000 they illegally spent by making certain that all returned envelopes went back to the divisional returning officers. If they did not, I wonder whether the Minister will, in this conciliatory mood in which he suggested I do something about the State Government, make certain that his colleagues send all the failed letters back to the divisional returning officers if they have not.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I particularly want to make is this: Senator McKiernan said that he did not want to be inundated with paper, particularly in an electorate like Kalgoorlie. Surely in these times of modern technology the simplest thing to do would be to give us all a disc. The Electoral Commissioner could simply give us a compatible disc; although the Government's equipment purchases seem to be determinedly along the lines of not buying equipment that is compatible, so maybe that would not work. Surely material could simply be given to us on disc. We would not need reams of paper; we could press a button and sticky labels could emerge in our office without involving the Electoral Commissioner in such problems.

I am just wondering whether the Electoral Commission makes any enrolment information available either commercially or to other people in this way. It does not seem to me to be a problem to give us discs, unless there is some confidential information on the discs. For example, we no longer get people's occupations in the way we used to, and that kind of confidentiality could be maintained if an appropriate button were pressed when transferring information from one disc to another to enable us to have a disc.

Can the Minister also tell us how many electorates and which ones were in the sample of the check on how bad the rolls were? If that information is confidential it would be a disappointment because it is reasonable for us to be advised of the electorates so we can see whether they are Labor- or Liberal-held electorates that have been checked in this way.

The final point I make is that, through the fog of information that settled over the Minister at Estimates Committee time, he has confused questions I asked with those asked by Senator Parer. Having gone back, at last I can see what prompted the Minister's obvious befuddled state. Nevertheless, Senator Parer's questions also merit a more coherent answer than the ones we got in Estimates hearings. Senator Parer made the point that these broader direct mails, across the whole spectrum of the enrolment list, have a very large failure rate. That is why the direct mail that all the Labor candidates were involved in illegally would have had a large failure rate, too. Senator Parer asked Mr Cox:

I understand that, but with political parties engaged in direct mail and with the state of the rolls as they are, what sort of returns would you expect of envelopes which state that either the person is not at that address, has moved or whatever?
Mr Cox, the Commissioner, responded:
I would have thought that we would not have that information.
Senator Parer asked:
Have you had any complaints on this following the election from particular areas?
There were complaints of a massive failure rate on the printed rolls, or certainly within a very short time of the final printed rolls. Mr Cox in reply said:
Not of that kind.
Senator Parer pressed him and said:
You have had no direct complaints?
Mr Cox said `No', and added:
That is the first I have heard of it. That is returns to parties?
Senator Parer said, `Yes'. Mr Cox continued:
No. That information would not come to us, except in an anecdotal way, and I have not even heard that.

This strikes me as not just incredible but also appalling. It would seem to me to be absolutely essential that, in a pre-election environment, when we get such an enormous failure rate at least the Electoral Commissioner would be advised by the divisional returning officers of a pretty substantial failure rate. I know that divisional returning officers are very busy in the run-up to an election, but we were asking questions of the Electoral Commissioner on 15 May-1 3/4 months after the election. Surely in that period, even by anecdotal means, the Electoral Commissioner should have become aware of this failure rate. Senator Parer sends in his failure rate, I send in mine, and looking around this chamber, other senators, including Senator Teague, send in theirs. To think that the Commissioner has not been advised, even anecdotally, by divisional returning officers suggests that there is a clear need for some mechanism, which is what I asked for when I first started talking about this matter an hour or so ago.

Instead of just saying, `No, there is no mechanism; no, I do not understand what you are talking about; no, I have something to hide', can the Minister give us some information on this matter? Because it has taken such an effort to get anything out of the Minister on this issue, I am wondering what the Government has to hide on this question. Why has it been so reluctant to ensure that the Electoral Commissioner is fully informed? Why is the Minister not saying, `Yes, we will look into that matter and get some kind of information channel up', so there is some sort of guideline about what is an unacceptable failure rate, so the divisional returning officers know they have an obligation to let the Commission know that the rolls were in a pretty hairy state, if they were, before the last election? SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to this debate in my office and I would like to put my own personal experience as a senator on the public record. I write to new enrolments on the rolls in four Federal electorates in Queensland-all Labor-held. Some of them are quite marginal. Over the years my office has averaged between five and six letters per block of 300 new enrolments returned endorsed `Not known at this address, return to sender'. That is nearly 2 per cent. We are pretty confident of those figures.

SPEECH.PARA: For years we advised the Electoral Commissioner that these people were not at the address that was on the new roll. Nothing seemed to happen about that and in recent times we have ceased advising the Commissioner and we are just watching the rolls to see whether these names are deleted. So far I cannot pass an opinion on that point. It is not a matter of dwelling on the fact that maybe 2 per cent on the electoral roll are phantoms and put on by the Australian Labor Party, presumably; it could well be higher than that.

In the first place, if the electoral rolls are being rigged, and rigged carefully and intelligently, when a letter arrives from me and the person at the address opens it because my name-Senator MacGibbon-is on the front and he finds it is a welcome to the electorate letter and just puts it in the waste paper basket, I cannot recognise that as a non-return. I do not know that that person does not exist. So the figures of phantoms on the rolls may well be higher. If we are dealing with a figure, in my experience, of about 2 per cent of people who are not on the rolls-that is about 1,400 in an electorate of 70,000-it is more than enough to win that electorate. If we look at electorates that are closely contested, such as Fisher and Dawson, to name but two of them in Queensland, and if a party can put 2 per cent of phantoms on for its side, it is doing very well.

The interesting thing is that the very high percentage of these non-returns come from people in caravan parks, lot so and so in a suburb or a small town, or from a post office in country towns. Given the closeness of results in many electorates, I find the whole matter very disturbing. Elections in this country are won or lost on marginal seats, and if the system by which the polling takes place is not accurate there is not much point in having an election at all. Already we have the situation where the boundaries are rigged because we have a government in power which, for a second term of office, is a minority government. It failed to get anywhere near the number of votes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether, in talking about boundaries and so on, we are straying from the Additional Estimates at this stage.

—What Senator MacGibbon is saying is relevant to the maintenance of electoral rolls. I saw nothing out of order in that. There have been some comments by way of aside, but I think they are inevitable in this matter.
—I wish to add my personal experience to that of my colleagues on this side of the chamber who are profoundly concerned about the accuracy of the electoral rolls that we are now being issued with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may be able to satisfy some of the points that Senator Crichton-Browne may wish to raise. I refer to Senator Michael Baume's earlier point about direct mail-outs and whether information was made available to the Australian Electoral Commission. I am advised that it is generally a normal practice of some members to provide information about the return of direct mail-outs, but we do not have any information as to who may have done it this particular time. I am informed that the use of discs is an expensive mechanism. It is made available to each of the parties once every three years. It is not commercially available and would be an expensive thing to make available to everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume mentioned a survey. I think he was concerned that the survey would be politically biased. I am informed that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, in its recommendation as to the conduct of this survey, recommended that two electorates be surveyed after the 1990 election. The Electoral Commission is surveying six electorates-two marginal electorates for each party and two so-called controls. The field work has been completed; the analysis is still being completed. It would be premature to give the names of those electorates, but we will consider that matter in six to eight weeks when the work is completed.

Senator MacGibbon raised the question of phantom voting, as have others, and that matter is being addressed as part of the survey. The people who are being investigated are those who enrolled as being new to the electorate, from outside the electorate, and have voted, that is, those people who enrolled somewhere in the vicinity of four to six weeks-I do not have the specific timeframe-before the closing of the rolls. Thirty-eight thousand names are being checked and 36,000 different addresses are being checked to ensure that the survey is being conducted fully and adequately. It is fair to say that this is one of the most comprehensive and far-reaching surveys of this nature to be conducted-not only by this Electoral Commission, but probably by any other in the world. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not raise the question of phantom voters; I raise what anybody with a suspicious mind might describe as phantom votes. I refer the Minister to the mobile polling booths which are used in remote parts of the States. Let me give an example--
—Order! Are you going to relate this to the subject we are looking at, which is the maintenance of electoral rolls and mail returned from bulk mail-outs? Can you relate this matter to that area?

They showed what the Minister would judge as devastating precision in terms of their deliberations, as 98.6 per cent of them chose the Labor Party as their first preference.
—Senator, you will still have to bring it back to the subject we are discussing.

—Mr Chairman, I am. It is a slow and tortuous process. I am seeking to explain, first, the cost of those booths and, secondly, the certainty and reliability that those casting votes are actually not listed on more than one roll. —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Senator Crichton-Browne is always very comprehensive in the presentation of his case, but I think that we have got this particular point. Can he canvass areas that are relevant to the subject of the Committee at this particular stage, without going into this area? We do not really know whether it relates to the point or not.

—I have spoken to Senator Crichton-Browne. He assures me that he is going to relate it to the matter before the Chair which is the maintenance of electoral rolls and taking account of reports of mail returned following bulk mail-outs.

—Mr Chairman, it is. I am sorry if I offend the Minister by having to go into some detail to arrive at the question, but I think there is no more lucid or sophisticated way in which I can do it. I refer to the teams of electoral officers who fly around, at enormous expense to the taxpayer, to collect votes in remote areas. One finds, for instance, that the first team, as it travelled around these remote areas, relying on the electoral roll to determine who is entitled to vote, attracted 164 formal votes and eight informal votes-that is a 95.3 per cent strike rate. Of those, 91.5 per cent, or 150, cast their first vote for the Labor Party and one vote was for the Liberal Party, which means that we got 0.6 per cent of the vote.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the second team, there were 428 formal votes cast and three informal-that is a 99.3 per cent formal vote. It is remarkable by any measure. Of those, 387, or 90.4 per cent, cast their first vote for the Labor Party and 2.8 per cent for the Liberal Party. At Mount James, 22 formal votes were cast, there was not one informal vote, and 86.4 per cent of those cast their first vote for the Labor Party and 4.5 per cent for the Liberal Party. I have selected those figures randomly. At Beagle Bay, for instance, 99 formal votes were cast and one informal-which means a 99 per cent formal vote-and 85.9 per cent of those were cast for the Labor Party.

In those remote areas the Australian Labor Party vote averaged between 85 per cent, at the very worst box, and 100 per cent. The vote of the Liberal Party of Australia was as low as 0.6 per cent while, in one devastating box, we actually got 10.8 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have to look into that one.
—Yes, Senator Colston must look for the names to see who were the delinquent 11 who cast a vote for the Liberal Party.
—That is just the point Senator Colston makes. The Labor Party undoubtedly has a list of those names.

—Absolutely. The vote for the Labor Party in the Federal seat of Kalgoorlie, where each of those boxes was located, was 47.7 per cent. Yet, the votes for the Labor Party went up to 100 per cent-at their very worst they were 85 per cent-in these remote and isolated areas.
—Maybe they don't like your policies.

—Yes. I am sure they have sat down and read our policies on land transport, aviation deregulation and privatisation and said, `We'll have the Labor Party'. I have no doubt that that is what compellingly and inexorably drove them towards voting for the Labor Party! The tragedy is that under this Government then can neither read nor write. They have been led and fed by these white advisers--
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, you are straying very far from the issue.

—I am sorry, Mr Chairman. I should not have been tempted by that interjection. The Labor Party attracted 47.7 per cent of the vote and the Liberal Party 31 per cent. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would say, even the Government could understand that there is a distortion and a skewing in the vote. If one looks at the informal vote in these areas one sees that it is dramatically less than the average for Kalgoorlie and for Australia as a whole. This begs the question: Given that the Aboriginal communities in these areas are, by any measure, unsophisticated-many of them sign their names with a cross rather than their name-how does the Department determine with any certainty, that they are not on the roll two or three times? If they are using the postal voting system, how does it determine that they do not vote two or three times? That leads me to ask the question: What remarkable education process is available in these booths but is not available to the rest of the Australian society so denying other Australians the opportunity to be so perceptive in casting a vote and casting it in a formal manner.

—The first question Senator Crichton-Browne asked was clearly in order. We are discussing the matter of whether their names are on the electoral roll more than once. At this stage, the second part is not relevant to what we are discussing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with Senator Crichton-Browne in expressing concern about the cost related to the remote area mobile polling. A very similar situation to that outlined by Senator Crichton-Browne arose in many communities in the Northern Territory, particularly the Aboriginal communities. In the circulated supplementary answer to a question which details all of the costings it is noted that some 147 places in the Northern Territory were visited and that some 10,198 votes were issued. From recollection, of those 10,000 votes in the Northern Territory the House of Representatives vote for the Country-Liberal Party totalled approximately 1,600.

SPEECH.PARA: The sad saga of this event is that there is no such thing as a secret vote in remote area mobile polling in Aboriginal communities. One of the conflicting principles of this issue is the way that assistance is given to people who often claim to be illiterate. Whilst I accept that there is a very high proportion of illiterate voters, there is also a very significant number of Aboriginal constituents who are not illiterate but still claim assistance in completing their voting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling, you are starting to suffer from the same problem as Senator Crichton-Browne. You must relate your remarks to the maintenance of the rolls rather than the voting procedures, which is not a matter before the Chair at the moment. We are on the subject of the Electoral Commission procedures for the maintenance of electoral rolls and taking account of reports of mail returns following bulk mailings.

—I share Senator Crichton-Browne's concern, particularly about the statistics, which I do not have readily available. It is also very interesting to note the enrolment numbers in each of the places visited and the number of people who actually voted. There are significant discrepancies between the actual enrolments in each location and the numbers that voted and how that transposes to the costs of the Electoral Commission. The Commission obviously makes decisions about which community to take the remote mobile polling booth to according to the enrolments in that community. When there is a turnout of only 10, 20 or 30 per cent at a polling booth in a community, the basis on which the Commission has made extensive decisions about finances must be seriously questioned.

—Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. I wonder whether we are straying into the general question of mobile polling and not, as indicated by you earlier, relating our contributions to the actual maintenance of the roll. If I were to answer Senator Tambling's question I would not be addressing this part of the Estimates Committee report.
—I have drawn Senator Tambling's attention to this. As I understood his remarks, he was moving around to the problems of electoral rolls in mobile polling booths. If he was, he is in order.

—The two matters are intricately linked to the maintenance of the rolls. For example, the number of votes issued in the Northern Territory is 10,000, yet, the numbers on the rolls is in many cases much greater. I was trying to ascertain how the Department made the decision to spend $106,000 visiting those communities. Whilst it is certainly academic and interesting to note the political consequences of the lack of a secret ballot and the manner in which the costs are imposed on scrutineers and officials, this issue needs to be very seriously addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of points have been raised. I think Senator Crichton-Browne made a point about the assistance provided to Aboriginal voters by providing mobile polling booths in these remote areas. In order to be pertinent to the question of accuracy of the electoral roll, we have local electoral assistants in these areas who belong to the communities and who identify voters at the time of polling. That is one way of ensuring that we know who is voting. However, Aboriginal people, like migrants and people who are illiterate, are covered by the provision normally available in the Commonwealth Electoral Act-the avenue of assisted voting. Having spent a lot of time years ago trying to help people in migrant communities to vote, I know that there is nothing more frustrating than seeing totally confused elderly people attempting to vote-and knowing full well whom they wanted to vote for-but being incapable of--
—There is nothing more frustrating for a Liberal scrutineer than watching a Labor stooge fill in a card.

—There is probably something more frustrating than that for Senator Crichton-Browne: his being over there and our still being over here. I hope that he suffers for a lot longer. It is totally frustrating watching those people trying to vote. The point is that people can, and obviously do, avail themselves of this particular provision of the Electoral Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Tambling raised a point about a suspected discrepancy between the numbers who vote at a mobile polling booth as opposed to those who live in communities. As a representative of the Northern Territory, Senator Tambling probably knows full well that in this process there is a hub community and that those from outer areas have access to the mobile polling facility in that community. Quite often, there is an arrangement that allows people from outside that community to vote at a mobile booth. The other thing that happens with voting generally is that people may not be in their community on the day of the poll. For example, they could be in Alice Springs, Darwin or Katherine. As a consequence, there may be discrepancies in that area as well. I think that answers all the questions that have been raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) and to the Australian Electoral Commission that at the next Estimates hearings we will expect a careful account of the management of the electoral roll at the divisional level and, in summary, across the whole nation. The questions that have been raised today should be no surprise to the Senate. Many senators have been involved in the last hour and a half in this committee stage discussion of matters that were considered by Estimates committees.

SPEECH.PARA: The primary question is the integrity of the electoral roll. A 98 per cent integrity is not good enough because we have the clear knowledge that the last election was decided on the basis of less than one per cent of the vote in a dozen electorates. Therefore, with the last general election very freshly in our minds, it should come as no surprise that, when the estimates of the Australian Electoral Commission, which comes under the Department of Administrative Services, are before us, we should ask, `What is the management system for ensuring the integrity of the electoral roll?'.

Questions have been asked by Senator Michael Baume, Senator Parer, Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Tambling, Senator MacGibbon and me. We are not satisfied that the Government or the Electoral Commission has a management system in place that will demonstrate to this chamber and to the public that there is a 100 per cent-or very close to that; say, 99.99 per cent-integrity in the electoral roll.

Given the use of computers and management techniques, facilities are available to the Electoral Commission to post in on a monthly basis in a straightforward and comprehensive table the number on the roll in a particular month, the number of deletions, the number of additions and the number of corrections with regard to 150 electorates over 36 months. This information should be able to be notified not only in respect of a division but also on a comprehensive basis across the whole country. That kind of careful management has not been demonstrated in terms of its impact upon us or in the answers that have been given to the Estimates Committee or here today. When we come to the Estimates following the August Budget, we will be looking carefully for a management system that will give greater accountability and certainty and satisfy senators of all parties that there is integrity in the electoral roll.

The second reason for all of these questions and concerns is that we, as members of parliament, need to communicate in a regular way to people in the many electorates. In order to do that, we need accuracy. When we find inaccuracy, or allegations of inaccuracy, we want to know what response is given to each item of information that we give to the divisional officers of the Electoral Commission.

I think in the committee stage debate of the Appropriation Bills we have demonstrated that we need assurances. Over the coming months there should be put in place a management system which not only achieves the goals we have been pressing for but also which is actually seen by individual senators to be working in the months leading up to September and October when we will be asking very carefully for the Electoral Commission's answers on this management question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague made a number of allegations and inferences. Specifically, he has asked for two things. A bit of considered debate might be more appropriate. He has asked for two mechanisms to be made available to ensure the openness of the system. In both cases, they are available. South Australian and Western Australian senators can get the corrections. The fact that Senator Teague does not get them may reflect the fact that the information is not coming through to him or it may reflect something else. But I am advised that South Australian and Western Australian senators can get the corrections. All they have to do is ask for them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague made a grand speech about what is integral to the honesty and integrity of the roll and so on. Once again, Senator Teague can get the information. He should not talk about some great Cecil B. de Mille production that will come before the Estimates Committee later this year. Write us a letter, mate, and we will provide the information to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister does not help by making ironic statements in response to genuine contributions made in this committee stage of the debate. Of course, I can write a letter. Of course, I can do a number of things. Anyone who has been listening to the debate in this chamber this morning, will know that we are not satisfied and that it has not been demonstrated to us that there is a management system in place which meets the criteria that I and others have described during the committee stage. Without any drama, I just bring to the attention of the Government and the Australian Electoral Commission that we want to see that management system in place and demonstrated to us in practice in the months leading up to the Estimates Committee hearings in September and October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be quite brief. Earlier on, when I was still in my office, I heard the Minister explain away the return of letters that were sent to some of the more isolated divisions. I think he mentioned Kalgoorlie.
—I never mentioned Kalgoorlie.
—Someone mentioned Kalgoorlie.
—It was Senator McKiernan.

—That is right. Senator McKiernan said that a 2 per cent return of letters in respect of Kalgoorlie could be quite normal because of the floating mining population. But I have had a different experience. Earlier this year, I conducted a mail-out to a cross-section of people living in the outer metropolitan seat of Canning in Perth, advising them of where my office was, and what it could do for them, if they needed any help. I had a return of roughly 1 3/4 per cent which, of course, is lower than the experience in Kalgoorlie. I think the Minister might find this funny, but I have kept all the returns and I can show them to him. Of the 1 3/4 per cent-this is quite a big packet-only one return was sent back marked `junk mail'. The recipient has the perogative to make such a decision.

SPEECH.PARA: The bulk of the letters that were sent back were marked `Address unknown'. If a letter turns up at a house, even though the previous occupier may have moved, there is generally an address available to forward it on to. It seems peculiar to me that 97 per cent of the returned ones had `Address unknown' written on them. One would think that at least 50 per cent of people would be bothered to readdress the letters that were sent to that address rather than mark them `Address unknown, return to sender'.
The other aspect that I found funny or peculiar is that I did a mail-out to explain what my office was about to all the Italian families in the electorate of Canning, and I got one back.

TALK.START.PARA: —One letter?

—One letter came back marked `Changed address, forwarding address not available'. I suppose one could infer two things from that: first of all, that the Italians are more stable than the average Australian; and, secondly, that they will not be used as ghosts, stooges or something like that. I found it peculiar that, of the 400-odd letters sent out, I got one back. The others I got back-accounting for not quite 2 per cent-were all marked `Address unknown'.

SPEECH.PARA: If I could comment on mobile polling booths-I will be very brief-I was part of a mobile polling booth team this year, and we went to a couple of booths that we did not go to at the last election. We got some votes there this time, and some were informal whereas last time there were no votes that were not informal and no votes for us. I could carry on and set out some of the things that were said well away from the polling booths, but they are not part of the subject being discussed at present, and I will find an opportunity to mention those matters later on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raised the matter of cleansing the rolls. I do not think I got a satisfactory answer. I also raised the question of how certain the Australian Electoral Commission is that there is not some mobility between these nomadic voters; and what reasonable steps does one take to ensure, for instance, that there is the use not of skin names but of given names. In respect to this question of ghosting and people fraudulently putting themselves on the roll, or putting other people's names on the roll and so on, how many fraudulent enrollees has the Commission detected; and what is the typical penalty for that offence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Panizza, it is obvious from his experience compared to that of Senator Crichton-Browne that, if I were a Liberal Party candidate, I would have Senator Panizza out organising for me rather than Senator Crichton-Browne. He was not able to get any votes for the Liberal Party in the areas that he related. Congratulations! In answer to Senator Panizza's specific points, we are advised that a letter that is returned marked `Address unknown' is a normal procedural response. If we are talking about a mail-out to new electors--
—I said `Not known at this address'.

—If we are talking about a mail-out from Senator Panizza to new electors and he was getting that reply, then the Australian Electoral Commission would appreciate Senator Panizza passing on that information to it, as some other senators and members do. When mail-outs to new electors occur, that information would be useful as regards the overall objective of keeping the roll honest and would be acted upon and checked. However, as I mentioned earlier on, if Senator Panizza is talking about a mail-out as part of a general mail-out, using the computer tapes that might be available to parties and whatever, then the information on those tapes is recognised as being somewhat outdated, and that is not a cost productive way of ensuring follow-ups in those cases. But I think that Senator Panizza was talking about new enrolments.
—I wasn't. I did a random mail-out, and I picked out about every sixth one.

—That is fair enough. Going back to my earlier answer, we find that the most appropriate, convenient and useful mechanism for mail-outs is the returns on the new electors, and in those circumstances that information would be quite useful to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne asked what checks are conducted to ensure that we do not have double voting, given the mobility of electors. No-one tolerates in any way the old United States practice of vote early and vote often. We obviously do not in our system of government. We have in place an automatic procedure called a de-duplication process which is geared towards ensuring that people are not enrolled, for instance, in two particular areas, electorates or locations. That process was conducted last year before the election. That is an appropriate and effective mechanism to ensure that people are not doubly enrolled. Senator Crichton-Browne also asked another question.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were two questions: How many fraudulent enrollees has the Commission detected, perhaps in the last decade; and what is the typical penalty?

—In order to get a full, comprehensive and honest answer to that question, I think we will take it on notice and get back to Senator Crichton-Browne. Obviously, we would not have that information, particularly information concerning the last 10 years. I will provide a full answer to the Committee as soon as I can.
—What is the penalty?
—Under the Act?
—Yes. What is a typical penalty?

—Unless we can get an indication of how many cases we have had, where they were, where they were considered and what the actual penalty was, it is very hard to give an answer as to what the typical penalty is now. As for what is provided in the Act, I will not try to do a Barry Jones and give a figure. It is best that we let the Committee know the answer in due course. Every one of us is presumed to know the law.
—Are the officers who are present in the chamber able to recall one instance of fraudulent enrolment?
—We can recall an instance in Queensland last year, but we do not have the details and the amount of the fine decided upon by the magistrate.
—Is it a State or Federal occasion?
—It was a Federal case.
—So there's one in living memory?

—I would not say that, and I would not draw that conclusion. In answering the question, I was trying to be helpful, and in Senator Crichton-Browne's normal way, of course, he is just seizing on one part of the answer. We have indicated that we will try to get all the information for the Committee. Senator Crichton-Browne asked specifically whether an officer could remember one case, and I said that an officer can remember one, but that does not necessarily mean that that officer cannot remember more or that there is not another officer in the Commission who is better seized of the facts. Given that this sort of question comes right out of left field, I think a considered answer should be provided in the interests of a comprehensive response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point in debating this trivia, but I would not have thought that it came out of left field. I would have thought that it was the sort of matter that would be under active consideration by the Commission and that it would have some sort of working knowledge of the level of incidents inasmuch as after every election there are inevitably the same allegations.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the difficulty in detecting fraudulent enrolments, the Commission would have some idea of what is a typical penalty. But I am not asking the Minister to respond to that because he has already told me as much as he and the officers know. I bring him back to the answer he gave me in respect of the cleansing of the rolls. The Minister said there is a deregistration process--

TALK.START.PARA: —De-duplication. If there was one of those in the Senate we would not be doing this at the moment.

—The response I was going to make to that interjection would be out of order. Let me give what might be a typical example. Dickie Skinner is a full blood Aborigine, unemployed, living on benefits and nomadic, with friends, relations and acquaintances in Wiluna, Meekatharra, Mount Magnet, Leonora, Sandstone and Laverton. He has a police record in every one of those towns, which is indicative of his mobility. He enrols under the name of Dickie Skinner in Meekatharra. As a result, not of dishonesty but aberration, the Labor Party lines him up and gets him to enrol in Mount Magnet, because he cannot remember whether he has enrolled.
—He would vote Liberal anyhow, probably.

—If he was thoroughly informed he would vote Liberal, although I fear he might be persuaded by disinformation to cast a vote incorrectly. When he goes to Sandstone he sees another diligent Labor Party apparatchik and he uses his skin name. He goes to Wiluna and does what many of them do, and uses his mother's surname. What process is in place to ensure he is on the roll but once?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset that I do not intend to be provocative in saying this but I think it is a rather unfair representation of the Aboriginal people to be concentrating on them on this particular issue. The sort of question that Senator Crichton-Browne raises, quite honestly, can apply whether somebody is Aboriginal in a remote area, or living in the heart of Toorak in Victoria or other appropriate places in WA. If people have this sort of malevolent intent we have mechanisms in place to try to stop it. We believe those mechanisms, in terms of checking, go as far as any system can go.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Crichton-Browne has instances like the ones he is talking about we would obviously very much like to hear of them. But to seize on an Aboriginal person-mythical though he might be-and describe that particular person in a deprecating way is a totally unfair bias in this debate. Let us have a fair description of the people we are talking about.

In terms of this particular area I will answer directly the issue that Senator Crichton-Browne raises without going to the padding, which I find quite offensive. We have Aboriginal field officers. We have listings of both European and skin names. Those Aboriginal field officers assist the Commission in locating those people who may be registered more than once. Those field officers assist in a very constructive and positive way, working through the communities with the Commission.

I ask Senator Crichton-Browne, if he has a specific case, to put it up. We find in this area that quite often there is a lot of anecdotal evidence and mythology. If the Opposition wants to spend government resources pursuing that sort of stuff, I would hate to see what the deficit would be if it was in government.

Let us acknowledge that we are talking about an Electoral Commission which is independent of government, and has been set up after consideration of a report by the Parliament. It is run by persons who are independent of government-for instance, I cannot direct them as their Minister. Let us acknowledge that there is no bias within the system. If one loses an election obviously one gets sour about it, and I have felt sour in the past as well. But let us also acknowledge that what the Commission is doing in this area, in terms of the de-duplication process, the survey that has been conducted since the election and so on, has provided very good instruments geared towards ensuring that we have an honest roll and honest elections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fascinating that Senator Bolkus finds something distasteful or offensive about me referring to a particular section of the Australian community.
—They do the same in Toorak and Lygon Street.

—I am surprised that Senator Bolkus is steeped in such a depth of ignorance that he can compare what happens in Lygon Street or Toorak with the capacity for mobility in the remote parts of Western Australia. Simply by virtue of their lifestyle--
—John Elliott is registered in the Cocos Islands, for instance. He is a floating company director all over the world. He has no fixed address and he used to run the Liberal Party.
—Order! There are too many interjections from the Minister.

—The reason I have referred to Bayulu, Beagle Bay, Kalumburu, LaGrange, Lombardina, One Arm Point, Oombulgarri, the central reserve, Jigalong, Mount James and the three remote teams is that 99 per cent of the voters are Aborigine. Tragic as it may be, they are almost all illiterate and innumerate. A look at the level of formal voting shows a distortion of the national average. It begs a question.

SPEECH.PARA: For the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) to turn his back and wander around does not change the facts. When one looks at the vote one sees box after box contrary to the national, State and local average. The votes cast in favour of the Labor Party were 92.1 per cent, 98.6 per cent, 92.3 per cent, 89 per cent and 85.9 per cent, and the Minister wonders why I raise this matter.

I raise it because, quite frankly, I question the integrity of the voting. I am not questioning the integrity of the voters. I am asking whether there is a mechanism in place that prevents the corruption which is widespread in the north of Western Australia as the result of the manipulation of the Aboriginal community by thugs, bullies and Labor supporters.

If the Minister thinks he will put me off by suggesting there is something distasteful about raising the matter, I have news for him. I will pursue it until I am satisfied with the answers, and the Minister has not satisfied me that there is any comparison between Lygon Street and Wiluna. The truth of the matter is many of those Aborigines are mobile; they go from settlement to settlement and invariably they stay but for a few days with their friends and relations. They move from one centre to another centre for ceremonies, funerals, celebrations or for the sheer pleasure of it.

Almost without exception they have no fixed abode, unlike somebody who lives in Toorak. People do not live in the park in Toorak, then flit across to a park in another suburb. The normal lifestyle for these people, basically, is to live as fringe dwellers, tragically, with friends and relations on Aboriginal reserves on the edge of town. It is very difficult to detect them in the same way as when they are being sought for other reasons there is great difficulty in locating them. I asked what arrangements the Government has in place. Senator Bolkus gave me an analogy and said that he had satisfied me. He has not. I am not reflecting upon the integrity of the Australian Electoral Commission; I have no reason to do so. I think that it does a good job under difficult circumstances. In some respects, I think its cleansing of the roll is more efficient and effective than it has been in the past-but it is far from good enough.

The Minister tells me that he has officers who go around these communities. I would like him to tell me how many officers there are; what their terms of reference and responsibilities are; how they are engaged; what training they are given--

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly in remote areas.
—Yes, particularly in remote areas. Also, does the Minister have any tangible evidence of the results of their endeavours?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I make it very clear to the Senate that I will not try to satisfy Senator Crichton-Browne. I never have; I know my limitations. Senator Crichton-Browne should not use that as a benchmark in terms of my responses. In terms of ensuring that people are not bullied and whatever else Senator Crichton-Browne fears in these circumstances, let us get back to basics, back to the facts. If Senator Crichton-Browne has allegations he should put them up. If he has not, he should shut up.

SPEECH.PARA: The law provides-as Senator Crichton-Browne and every other member of parliament should know-for parties and candidates to have scrutineers inside the polling area on election day, at the time of polling. If he is concerned about these things we will put someone in there. He should not raise allegations unless there is substance to them.

I made the point about the bias in what Senator Crichton-Browne raised that people are mobile wherever they are. Mr Chairman, I know this is straying a little, but a case was reported on the weekend of a company director who has discovered the state of the art technology in tax avoidance and tax havens. Offshore companies can be used as tax havens and this person does not even have to be identified as the owner of shares; he does not have to provide a location for a meeting of company directors. This person is John Elliott. So Senator Crichton-Browne should not tell me that people are not mobile, no matter what their class structure, position or location in society. What I said to him is that if he is concerned about something he should not develop this picture of a mythical person, but give us some facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not taken a point of order because, like most of us, I rely on the integrity of Ministers' conduct in this chamber. To talk about John Elliott and tax evasion in the middle of the appropriations in respect of the voting procedures of north-west Western Australia touches along the lines of irrelevance. No doubt Senator Bolkus would have taken a point of order if it had been raised on this side of the chamber. I asked a series of questions when I last rose. I assume that I do not need to repeat them, so I will wait for the answers.
—One of the specific questions raised by Senator Crichton-Browne also demands a lot of information. That question will be taken on notice, and the answers provided.
—To the extent that we have officers in the chamber at present what level of knowledge is available to the chamber at this moment?
—I am advised by the officers that they would like to provide a considered and full response, and take the question on notice.

—I am not satisfied. I do not much care what the officers want. I am asking the Minister, for instance, whether he is able to describe for the Committee of the Whole the detailed responsibilities of these officers, who are employees of the Commission.

—The short answer to that is no. The long answer is that all the questions Senator Crichton-Browne asked in this respect go into a lot of detail. Answers will be provided as is normally done in these circumstances.
—I say for the record that I find it most unsatisfactory that there is not even a titillating piece of information available, given that we have eight officers present in the chamber on this matter.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. We have two officers from the Electoral Commission present.

—I apologise, there are two officers. But we cannot get the slightest bit of information. I will ask the question again: What steps are taken, using these officers, to ensure that there is not duplication by political supporters enrolling more than once?

—I think I answered this question earlier. We do have these officers; they do have rolls of European names and skin names; they go around continually checking the electoral rolls to ensure that there is no duplication. As I said, one concerted de-duplication process took place last year before the most recent Federal election.
—I ask the Minister: Does he acknowledge and accept that it is a simple process for somebody, by manipulation of these people, to have duplication on the roll?
—That is a hypothetical question and I am not so sure that it is appropriate.

—The Minister can refuse to answer the question if he wants to. I am asking: Is it possible for there to be duplication, given the circumstances I have outlined? The question is not hypothetical. An answer would give us an indication of whether the present procedures in place are adequate or inadequate.

—I do not know how many times I have to explain this. I am sure that Senator Crichton-Browne can understand it. The mechanisms are in place to ensure that this sort of procedure either does not take place or is minimised. If that is the reason they are in place, one would anticipate that this sort of procedure is possible. If Senator Crichton-Browne did not anticipate that it were possible, if we did not anticipate it were possible, then I do not know what we are on about.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports by Amnesty International expressing the fear that killings of Palestinians by Israeli forces might be `condoned and even encouraged' by the Israeli Government? In the light of the recent escalation of violence, including killings by the Israeli police and military, and growing international concern about a wide range of human rights abuses, can the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's attitude towards the current situation in the occupied territories and its effect on prospects for negotiations towards a settlement in the Middle East? Can the Minister inform the Senate also of the Government's attitude to the question of Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel and, in particular, to the occupied territories, which appears to be significantly adding to the present tensions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen references to the Amnesty International report to which Senator Beahan refers. Certainly I express my profound hope that the suggestion that the killing of Palestinians by Israeli forces may have been condoned or encouraged by the Israeli Government is not correct. It is difficult to believe that it could be correct. Nevertheless, the past few days have witnessed some of the worst violence seen in Israel and the occupied territories since the start of the Intifada in December 1987.

ANSWER.PARA: On Sunday, 20 May, as has been widely reported, a gunman described as a former Israeli soldier opened fire on a group of unarmed Palestinian Arabs near Tel Aviv, killing seven and wounding a number of others. Following news of this incident, rioting broke out in Gaza and the West Bank and in putting down the riot a further seven people were killed and hundreds were injured when Israeli troops fired into crowds.

In further violence, at least another six Palestinians have been reported killed by the Israeli Army. There have also been repercussions in Jordan with several French tourists wounded in an attack by a Palestinian, apparently in reaction to the events in Israel and the territories. Demonstrations have taken place in Palestinian camps in Jordan leading to clashes between Palestinians and Jordanian security forces.

I note that the perpetrator of the original incident on Sunday has been arrested and that the Israeli Government has condemned the murder in the strongest terms and said that the incident will be fully investigated. While I very much welcome this, I must express, on behalf of the Australian Government, in the strongest possible terms, our deep concern at the subsequent actions of the Israeli security forces in putting down the Palestinian reaction to the murders. In the past Australia has condemned Israel's use of live ammunition against unarmed civilians and I have to repeat that condemnation in response to these latest incidents.

A particularly disturbing aspect of this latest wave of violence is that it has spilled over from the occupied territories into both Israel and Jordan. This escalation and the spreading of violence only reinforces the view that we have expressed on many occasions: that the Intifada will persist until its political causes are addressed-that is to say, until there is progress towards a settlement of the Arab-Israeli dispute.

Inevitably, this latest violence will serve only to harden attitudes on both sides and, once again, set back the search for peace in the Middle East. The continuing violence reinforces the need for all parties to the dispute to move towards establishing a genuine dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians in the context, most reasonably, of the proposals put forward last year by the United States Secretary of State, James Baker.

With regard to the last part of the question about the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel, estimates by Israeli officials concerning the total number of Soviet Jews who may arrive in Israel over the next three to five years vary between 250,000 and 700,000. I would like to make it very clear that Australia wholeheartedly welcomes developments in the Soviet Union which have allowed Soviet Jews to emigrate. This is an issue on which Australia pressed the Soviet Union for several years.

While nobody can have any possible objection to the migration of such Soviet Jews to Israel, I, on behalf of the Australian Government, however, share the concern expressed by a number of other countries that some of these new migrants have been allowed to settle in the occupied territories and that the Israeli Government is apparently willing to allow an increase in these numbers. It is obvious that continued movement into the occupied territories, including east Jerusalem, does not encourage Palestinians to pursue a negotiated path towards a dialogue with Israel. Again, I urge Israel and all other parties to the dispute to refrain from actions which might jeopardise the prospects of peace in the region.

In 1982 they formed 18.1 per cent of all working days lost through industrial disputation, but by 1988 the figure had risen to 52.4 per cent.
