There are a variety of reasons for the problem, including a failure to consult properly, outmoded management-worker relationships, a failure to embrace the principles of a more cooperative workplace relationship and a more participative mode of management, and poor training by middle management and by some shop stewards in industrial relations.

The Government allocated $12m for the workplace reform program in 1989-90. The three main elements of that program are: workplace resource schemes, under which regional centres will provide advice and support for enterprises on award restructuring and workplace reform; workplace training, which provides for the training of management and union personnel in participative practices and organisational change; and work change assistance, which provides support to employers and unions to help them undertake award restructuring and workplace reform projects and activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, yes.

—Senator Walters may have no interest in this subject at all, which indicates her abysmal level of knowledge about industrial relations. It is important to conclude this answer by saying that there has been a dramatic reduction, which appears to be a built-in reduction, in industrial disputes during the accord years. The focus on elements of what gives rise to disputes is an important priority of the Government in order to bring that figure even lower.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask that the Minister table the paper from which he was reading in answer to that question. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. What progress has been made to fulfil the election promise made by the Prime Minister that a Federal environment protection authority would be established? —Did the Minister for Social Security tell the Senate three times yesterday that, if one looks at the profiles of the long-term unemployed, which he defined as those who had been on benefits for more than 12 months, one sees that they are those in the older age group? How does he reconcile such statements with the fact that the latest quarterly survey of unemployment benefit recipients published by his own department shows that, as at November 1989, more than two-thirds of the long-term unemployed were aged less than 45 years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made the point several times yesterday and I will make it again for the benefit of Senator Alston and anyone interested: the greatest problem we will have with the Newstart program during the next few years will be to get people over the age of 50 off unemployment benefits-on Newstart, as it will become-and back to work. Those people are a hard core group and the hardest to place for obvious reasons. I said that several times yesterday. I repeat it now. That is a fact.

ANSWER.PARA: There are other factors that influence those who have been on unemployment benefits for longer than 12 months. Some problems are merely those of location. One wonders how we will be able to address those. In some areas, particularly for the unemployed in country areas who have been on benefits for longer than 12 months, it is virtually impossible to get a job. There are simply no jobs available in the areas in which they live. Obviously, many people in that category will be a lot younger than 50 years-some of them will be in their twenties.

The most difficult problem for a government interested in trying to give the hard core unemployed a real chance-some retraining and back to work-will obviously be the group most at risk and most difficult to place, those in the over 50 age group.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand the magnitude of the difficulty faced by the Government-it is expecting to save only $21m from this restructuring. I ask the Minister whether he told the Senate yesterday:

QUESTION.PARA: If Senator Alston wants to look at the longer term unemployed and their profiles, quite obviously they are those in the older age bracket. It is much harder to get back to work when one is in one's fifties . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have answered the question.
—Just a minute and listen to the question. Senator Richardson said that the bulk of the long-term unemployed are in their fifties. The fact is--

QUESTION.PARA: Government senator interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —No. This is more like the Supreme Court but the opposition is not as good. Yesterday Senator Richardson said that the bulk of the long-term unemployed were those in their fifties. I ask him: is it not a fact, on his own statistics, that the bulk of them are under the age of 45?
—I have just answered the question. I do not intend to keep answering it.

—Can the Minister for Social Security inform the Senate what effect payments received via compensation or emergency relief by the victims of the Newcastle earthquake and the recent floods in New South Wales, Queensland and Gippsland will have on pensioner and beneficiary entitlements? Are these payments treated as income for the purpose of assessable income for pensioners and beneficiary recipients? Will this reduce their entitlements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Black and a number of other honourable senators have been asking for some time now how payments made to victims of the earthquake and the floods will be treated. Of course, some difficulties in that respect need to be cleared up, not simply by making pronouncements in the Senate but by making sure that those who are setting up funds to assist flood victims contact the Department of Social Security first so that they can determine just exactly what kind of arrangements will need to be made, particularly in the preparation of the deeds.

ANSWER.PARA: Section 3 of the Social Security Act specifically exempts from the definition of `income':
insurance or compensation payments made by reason of the loss of, or damage to, buildings, plant or personal effects;

In that context, we take compensation to have a pretty broad meaning-broad enough to encompass payments made from relief funds such as the Lord Mayor's fund in Newcastle and a number of other funds that have been set up for the flood victims. If the trust deed of any of those funds is framed in a way that allows payments for such purposes and the trustees make payments of those kinds to pensioners and beneficiaries, those payments will not be treated as income for pension or benefit purposes.

Similarly, as long as the money is spent fairly quickly on repairs or maintenance, the money will not be treated as an asset for assets test purposes. In most cases, of course, that will not matter because the amounts of money will be too small to affect the assets test. Obviously, since 13 June those thresholds have been reasonably high-$103,000 for single home owners, $177,000 for single non-home owners, $147,000 for married home owners and $221,000 for married non-home owners. They are reasonably high amounts and we do not anticipate that too many people will be affected because of this provision.

The Social Security Act does not count as income the value of emergency aid or other forms of emergency assistance. So the emergency payments that were made in the early period after the earthquake and after the floods do not present any problem at all. That would include the payments that were made directly by the governments of New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria and not simply the payments made by the Department of Social Security.

As with Newcastle, the flood victims in New South Wales, Queensland and, indeed, in Gippsland, in which Senator McGauran has shown such an interest, later received amounts to repair houses or replace belongings. Those amounts will not be taken into account in the assessment of pensions or benefits, provided that the conditions I referred to earlier are met. As I said earlier, it is most important that trustees of those funds contact the Department in the early stages so that they can make sure what provisions in the Social Security Act may apply to those payments.

Another contentious point that needs to be addressed is the proceeds of insurance claims and how they will be treated when they are paid to victims, although I understand that in the case of the floods there might not be too many who will be eligible for insurance payments. Under the legislation as it currently stands, payments made in respect of insurance claims that were made in the aftermath of the Newcastle earthquake are assessable as assets, at least until they are expended. In most cases, of course, they are going to be expended fairly quickly because people are anxious to get on with their lives and rebuild. Therefore, they will not present a problem. But just in case, the previous Minister wrote to the Prime Minister in February on this matter. We are discussing with the Prime Minister whether or not a 12-month exemption could be provided to people in that category.

In the case of Gippsland, the Department did not pay the double rate in affected areas because the impact in Gippsland was judged not to be as adverse as it was in New South Wales and Queensland. To make up for that, the Victorian Government was quick off the mark with its assistance in the form of emergency aid. Since then, we have received some 60 claims from the area for unemployment and other benefits. These are being processed very quickly. What longer term impact there may be on the agricultural sector and the job market is harder to ascertain. Perhaps market gardening in those areas will be fairly badly affected and we may see a rise in the number of people claiming unemployment benefit. We will keep that monitored and make sure that people are paid as soon as the claims come in.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to yesterday's decision by Cabinet regarding changes in the foreign ownership provisions relating to television station ownership. If the Government was concerned about the protection of Australia's cultural sovereignty, as the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, claimed, why has it continued to leave the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal without sufficient powers to deal with this matter? Is Mr Beazley's comment a reflection on the competence of the Tribunal to uphold things like broadcasting standards or local content requirements? Was the Government aware of any attempts, past or present, to employ contrived schemes to circumvent the current limits on holding companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can deal first with the last part of the question relating to contrived schemes to circumvent the ownership provisions: the legislation which allowed for those contrived schemes was introduced by a conservative government in 1981. If one follows the debate in the Senate by having a look at the Hansard of that day, one will find that I, amongst others, pointed out that there were loopholes in the legislation which would have to be dealt with at some stage in the future.
—It's taken a while, hasn't it?

—It has taken a while. That is at last being done by this Government, the provisions having been set up by totally inefficient legislation introduced by Senator Durack, who, as I recall, was Attorney-General at the time. Those are the circumstances with which the Government was confronted.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of cultural sovereignty, on the one hand, and ownership of television stations and local content and support for the local industry, on the other hand-the television production industry and so on-I think there is some confusion about that issue because of ownership requirements and the support of the local industry. Nonetheless, I think the higher the level of overseas ownership, the less likely it is that attention will be given by television proprietors to supporting the local industry.

I am not sure of the exact date or time, but I remind honourable senators that the Broadcasting Tribunal, to which Senator Sheil referred in his question, in fact introduced last year tighter and more strict provisions in relation to local content and that local content level is to be phased up. So I think if one studies what the Broadcasting Tribunal said about that, one will find that the Tribunal addressed that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and concerns the Coopers and Lybrand consultancy report which examined a tropical rainforest timber ban. Why has the report not been released and when will it eventually be released? Is it true that this report makes no recommendatons for restricting Australia's rainforest timber imports or for raising tariffs on such imports, and contains no specific proposals for increasing aid to halt tropical deforestation? Is the Minister aware that it is now 12 months since the previous Minister for the environment gave his personal commitment to restrictions on tropical timber imports and yet forest logging and destruction continues unabated? Furthermore, will the Minister, Mrs Kelly, be making any commitments to the Indonesian Minister of Forestry, Dr Harahap, when she meets with him this Friday? In conclusion, is the Minister aware that both the British and West German governments have taken the initiative to set up independent international rainforest conservation funds? Has this option been considered by the Australian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is normal practice for the Government to consider reports prior to their release. This report is currently being considered not merely by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories but by other relevant government departments. Once that consideration is concluded, Mrs Kelly will present a recommendation to the Government. After that, the report will be released. I am not exactly certain when that will occur, but at some stage in the next month or two I imagine that our consideration of it will be completed.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the honourable senator's question is: is it true that this report makes some recommendations? If we have not released the report I am hardly likely to confirm or deny what recommendations it may or may not make. The honourable senator will have to await its release.

The third part of the question is: am I aware that it is 12 months since the previous Minister gave his personal commitment to restriction? Yes, I am. Am I aware that forest logging and destruction continue unabated? Yes, I am, although there have been some improvements in the Asia-Pacific Basin in some countries with the production of better management plans. I think the situation may have slightly improved in the last 12 months, although I would not attempt to sugar-coat the picture-it remains bleak.

As far as commitments with the Indonesian Minister for Forests, Dr Harahap, are concerned, when Mrs Kelly meets him, I would have thought that she may wish to keep her own counsel on what she is going to talk to him about and what commitments they might make. Perhaps we should allow her to put that to him first rather than announce it in the Senate.

I was certainly not aware of the initiatives that the British and West German governments have taken to set up international rainforest conservation funds. The Senate will be aware that the Australian Government contributed to the fund set up by Sting during his visit here last year for the preservation of rainforests in the Amazon. We have certainly shown our willingness to contribute. I shall make sure that the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories examines what the British and West German governments have done and, if there is a lead for us there, I am sure we will try to follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given the Senate's rejection of the luxury car tax, and following the Treasurer's press statement in which he advised that no action would be taken against dealers who collected the tax from 1 May 1990, thereby encouraging dealers to collect the proposed tax because the alternative would have meant tracking down customers from 1 May and collecting the tax in arrears, what does the Government intend to do with car dealers who, in good faith, collected the proposed tax as of 1 May, given that the collection of the tax was, in fact, illegal? What does the Government plan to do to clear up the uncertainty and confusion in the automotive industry, and what advice has the Government for dealers?

—There are a number of questions here, some of which go into considerable detail. All I am able to say about that matter is that I understand that most of those questions are receiving urgent attention in the Treasury.
—It depends what Keating says you can say.

—Of course. That is one of Senator Walters's better interjections, if I might say so. When I represent the Treasurer in this place, I try to represent the Treasurer. I am saying to Senator Olsen, who has asked a serious question with a number of parts to it, that I will get an answer for him on that matter early next week, if I can, because there are a number of quite technical matters which I know are currently being considered.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is the Minister aware that Mr Wal Murray, who is hanging on by his fingernails as Deputy Premier of New South Wales--
—That's your interpretation.

—And Mr Greiner's. Is the Minister aware that Mr Wal Murray told the New South Wales Parliament that New South Wales country air services to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, are under serious threat? Is Mr Murray correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he is not. I did read Mr Murray's comments in the Parliament yesterday and, I must say, I made the same assumption as Senator Faulkner: that the statements had more to do with Mr Murray's leadership problems than with the factual situation at Kingsford-Smith Airport. In fact, I have met the rural airlink action group, which is a very representative organisation, representing most of the communities that use Kingsford-Smith Airport in regional New South Wales, and I could hardly have been more forthright in what I said to them. I noted afterwards that my views were canvassed quite properly in the press by the organisation.

ANSWER.PARA: What I said to it was that Kingsford-Smith Airport is Australia's most important international port, it is Australia's most important national port, it is also an important regional airport for the residents of New South Wales and the Government is not in the business of moving to exclude regional airlines from the use of Kingsford-Smith Airport. What I find to be extraordinary about Mr Murray's position on this-frankly, I would be interested to hear the views of the Premier of New South Wales on this-is that the people of New South Wales benefit to a more direct extent from the importance of Kingsford-Smith Airport in the first two categories that I have mentioned-that is, as an international port and a national port-than any other residents in Australia. It is vital for the residents of New South Wales that Kingsford-Smith Airport continue to be able to offer and operate efficient international and national services because they are the direct beneficiaries of it.

As I pointed out the other day in the Senate, the congestion problem at Kingsford-Smith Airport has to be addressed. The Government is addressing it on a number of fronts, design work has started on Badgery's Creek; a major upgrade of the air traffic control facilities at the airport is to commence and the third runway at Sydney Airport will be constructed if the environmental impact statement indicates that it is environmentally safe to proceed. But if all of that happens it will still not be sufficient to solve the congestion problems at Kingsford-Smith Airport.

Mr Murray's comments were based on a meeting that was held at officer level recently in New South Wales where the officers concerned quite properly put on the table-it would have been irresponsible for them to have done otherwise-all of the options that are currently being considered by government to address congestion at Kingsford-Smith Airport. The particular option that has excited the ire of Mr Murray is peak period pricing. I understand that is what he mentioned in the New South Wales Parliament yesterday. That had to be put on the table because it is a commonplace practice which is used at airports internationally to deal with traffic congestion.

A successful experiment was run last Easter Thursday which has become known as the Willoughby exercise. There was a voluntary arrangement by the airlines-the first for a long time; and I must say that I am pleased that the airlines agreed to do it-to reschedule their flights at Kingsford-Smith Airport. I am happy to provide any honourable senator who is interested with the detailed results of that Easter Thursday exercise, which significantly reduced congestion, not just at Sydney but also at Melbourne and Brisbane.

A further meeting will take place in the next week or two between the airlines to try to establish, if we can, a voluntary system of rescheduling flights in and out of Kingsford-Smith Airport similar to that which International Air Transport Association arrangements regarding international flights into Kingsford-Smith Airport. The reason I say that is to point out the obvious. I can provide this evidence to any honourable senator who has a real concern about Kingsford-Smith Airport.

It would not matter if the Government built a third, fourth, fifth or sixth runway at Sydney Airport. If we have airlines which advertise the fact that 20 aircraft will take off simultaneously at 7 a.m. from Sydney Airport, it will not happen, no matter what the Government does about it. That is the situation. It is commonplace for a number of airlines to offer departure and arrival times which are simply not able to be met. A lot of the responsibility initially, I hope, will be taken up by the airlines concerned to provide a rational arrangement of staggering aircraft departure and arrival times so that that extremely important facility at Kingsford-Smith Airport is utilised to the fullest extent. If the airlines cannot do that voluntarily, and we are giving them the opportunity to do so, then a solution will have to be imposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs continues to refuse to set up a royal commission, is he prepared to take official responsibility for the safety of the Hatton family?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be well know to all honourable senators that decisions as to royal commissions are taken by the Prime Minister. It is not my portfolio responsibility in that respect.
—What advice are you giving?

—The advice I have given is clearly along the lines that I have recounted to the Senate exhaustively over the last week or so. As far as Mr Hatton's personal safety is concerned of course I do not take responsibility for that safety. It is a matter for the proper authorities in New South Wales. I have already indicated to this chamber, I think in answer to Senator Vanstone, that I believe it is extremely important that Mr Hatton and his family be advised of any threats to his life or limb and some assessment be made of the likelihood of those threats being carried out. I think I issued something of a reprimand to the National Crime Authority in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot take responsibility for those threats which Mr Hatton and his wife have apparently received in the last 24 hours or so. I was upset that he should indicate in his statements yesterday that I was perhaps taking those threats less seriously than I should in relation to his call for a royal commission. Mr Hatton is not the only person in office, either as a parliamentarian or a Minister, dealing with organised crime who has received such treats. I have had policemen living in my lounge room in relation to death threats. I have had police cars parked outside my parents' home in response to death threats. Because of death threats I have had policemen sitting next to me when I go to the cinemas. I am well aware of what death threats are all about. I hope Mr Hatton is properly informed in a timely way so that the proper authorities can take adequate steps for his protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade been drawn to reports that the commander of the Fijian Armed Forces, Major-General Rabuka, intends to seek military aid from China, South Korea and Malaysia? Does the Minister regard the supply of military aid to Fiji by three major Asian powers as a threat to the delicate security and stability of the South Pacific region and to Australia's strategic interests within the region? What are the broader implications of these developments for Australia's relations with Fiji?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports that Major-General Rabuka claims to have laid the groundwork for future military assistance to Fiji from China, South Korea and Malaysia and that, according to the reports quoting him, assistance will be set up as soon as Fiji makes the formal approach. Fiji is, of course, a sovereign state quite entitled to make its own defence cooperation arrangements. I should say that such respect for sovereignty is quite fundamental to our policy of constructive commitment in the South Pacific. Nonetheless, it is an issue of continuing interest to us. We will continue to monitor carefully any arrangements which might emerge. However, on the information presently available to us we doubt that firm commitments have been made between Fiji and the countries to which Major-General Rabuka refers nor do I think that arrangements of any significance are likely in the reasonably foreseeable future.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the directions of current Australian policy towards Fiji are sound and I do not believe that media reports of Major-General Rabuka's travel in East Asia should somehow precipitate any review of those guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is going off to China because you won't reinstitute the defence cooperation program.

—I will cheerfully respond to Senator Hill. Our approach has consistently been to seek to shore up commitment to democracy and human rights while at the same time dealing with the objective realities of those in possession of power and authority in a country where Australian interests are substantial.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, of course, deplored both coups instigated by the Fiji military forces in 1987, and we continue to do so. We took a number of measures at the time to signal our abhorrence, including the recall of our High Commissioner and the suspension of civil aid and defence cooperation. Against the subsequent background of modest but steady improvement in Fiji's internal political and human rights situation since 1987, Australia has taken a number of steps toward a gradual normalisation of bilateral relations with Fiji, including the appointment of an ambassador, resumption of the civil aid program and resumption of ministerial and official contact on a wide range of issues. The exception is defence cooperation, the suspension of which remains firm. We have continued, and will continue, to make clear to the Fiji Government our hope that it will encourage a process of dialogue to arrive at an outcome to Fiji's problems which is broadly acceptable to all the communities there.

That approach is clear and straightforward but I notice that it has been the subject of a number of criticisms of varying degrees of stridency from the Opposition. For all the high minded rhetoric we have had from the Opposition, never once have we had an indication, from Senator Hill or anybody else, exactly how the Opposition would have acted differently in the three difficult years since the first coup in Fiji.

TALK.START.PARA: —On what terms and conditions would you reinstate the defence cooperation program? You are the Government. Tell us what Fiji has to do.
—Order! Senator Hill, this is a very long answer and you are encouraging a longer answer.

—I would like to add some point to Senator Hill's interjections by asking him just what the Opposition would have us do. Compare and contrast, for example, the tone of Senator Hill's statement on 14 May with that of Dr Hewson on 29 April. On the one hand we have Senator Hill, now occupying the Fred Chaney chair of applied sanctimony, speaking very disapprovingly of the Government having ignored the late Dr Bavadra and the views of the Opposition in Fiji generally, while on the other hand we have Dr Hewson positively advocating effective cooperation with the present Government of Fiji and, by very clear implication, advocating a resumption right now of defence cooperation. I would love to know what Dr Bavadra's widow, Adi Kuini Bavadra, who is in Canberra this week for talks with a number of people, thinks of that. It is precisely our measured and sensitive approach in not resuming the defence cooperation program that sends exactly the kind of signal that is understood by the Government in Fiji and appreciated by all those in that country who are seeking to restore democracy.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DEFENCE FORCES: SURVEILLANCE AND INTERDICTION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence and it relates to frequent incursions, principally by Indonesian fishing vessels, into Australian waters. What is the aggregate cost to the Australian defence forces of the surveillance and interdiction operations mounted by the Australian defence forces against those fishing vessels? Furthermore, can those tasks by the defence forces be comfortably accommodated within their annual budget or does the frequency of surveillance and interdiction mean that activities in other directions have to be restrained to accommodate them?

—I cannot give a precise cost but I will certainly obtain one for Senator MacGibbon on the cost of interdiction. Most of the surveillance costs are attributed to Coastwatch which, in the normal course of events, lets us know and requests our intervention. There is, of course, very little prospect of ever recovering any costs. The boats themselves are deliberately of very low quality so that when they are seized they cannot be sold. About the only fate for them is an annual burning and the sending of the photos back to Indonesian fishing villages as a warning. It is one of those civilian tasks that I think the defence forces must continue to do. I will get the figures on the cost of that interdiction and relay them to Senator MacGibbon as soon as possible.

—My question is about the tax excise on cigarettes. Can the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services advise whether the Commonwealth Government is considering changing the method of levying excise tax on tobacco in Australia? Will the Government be looking at the tobacco excise being based on tar content of cigarettes instead of the present method of basing the levy on the weight of cigarette packs? Reportedly the latter has allowed larger packs containing smaller cigarettes to be disproportionately cheaper and therefore more attractive to young smokers. Does the Government consider that the recommendation to base the excise on tar content will achieve a lower consumption rate for cigarettes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Questions as to excise, of course, are more correctly directed to the Commonwealth Treasurer as the question of Commonwealth tobacco excise is a matter for him. I am quite sure that I can refer elements of Senator Maguire's question to the Treasurer for examination. I think honourable senators will be aware that there is certainly no safe level or form of tobacco use, and that is the interest of the Community Services and Health portfolio.

ANSWER.PARA: Tobacco is the major preventable cause of death and disease in Australia. In fact, in 1987 there were 18,000 tobacco related deaths. The Federal Government is very concerned about tobacco consumption and has introduced major initiatives to address this problem, including banning smoking in Commonwealth buildings and on domestic airline flights and prohibiting the advertising of tobacco products in the electronic and print media. The Government is currently conducting a $2m national media campaign to reduce smoking by young women across Australia.

I think Senator Maguire's question may have been prompted by a report by the Victorian Office of Prices on cigarette pricing, consumption and health costs. That is a report on a study of the relationship between cigarette pricing, consumption and health costs and was released only last month. It has not yet been examined in detail by the Commonwealth Government. It makes several recommendations, including one that the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy develop a specific taxation strategy as part of its overall smoking control program. I believe that the Council of Ministers will meet on 9 June and perhaps this matter will be given consideration at that meeting. The questions raised by Senator Maguire are central issues for consideration and I believe that both the Treasurer and the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy will give them the very careful consideration they deserve.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 22 May, from Senator Jenkins:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
``The need for the Government to establish a Register of Foreign Ownership of Australian land, property, businesses and resources''.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
``The need for the Government to establish a Register of Foreign Ownership of Australian land, property, businesses and resources.''

There is rapidly growing alarm in this country over the extent of, and increase in, foreign ownership of Australian real estate and business. Of particular concern is that the extent and concentration of foreign ownership of Australian land, property, business and resources is known neither to the Government nor the public. This is because the Government has so far refused to respond to widespread community support for the establishment of a register of foreign ownership. The Australian Democrats have consistently advocated such a register for many years. My predecessor as Democrat senator for Western Australia, former Senator Jack Evans, introduced a private member's Bill into this place in 1984 to establish such a register.

Last year former Senator Janine Haines moved amendments during consideration of the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1988 to achieve the same result. Those amendments were defeated by a combined vote of Liberal, Labor and National Party senators. This morning I gave notice that the Australian Democrats will, before the end of this autumn sitting, reintroduce a private member's Bill to establish a national register of foreign ownership.

We have also pressed time and time again for increases in the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board-the FIRB-so that it can adequately monitor the level of foreign investment and assess whether or not particular proposals are in Australia's national interest. The Government's response has been to significantly reduce the capacity of the FIRB to carry out its tasks. Its staff has been reduced from 60 to 20. In its 1983-84 annual report the FIRB stated that it had rejected 4.2 per cent of foreign investment proposals. In 1986-87, less than 0.4 per cent were rejected.

Any development, trend or activity which has the capacity to significantly affect our economy or to affect the degree of control we have over our own destiny as a nation must be studied and monitored. The rapidly growing foreign ownership of Australian property, businesses and land could have a major impact upon our economy. If foreign ownership is concentrated in certain critical industries and activities in could lead to a situation where our State and Federal governments could lose effective control.

I want to make it absolutely clear that the concern of the Democrats is about purchases by nationals of all foreign countries equally, no matter where the investors in question are from. We are as concerned about British, American and Japanese investments as we are about investments of any other foreign nationals.

In order to understand foreign ownership and to understand to what extent and in what industries it may constitute a threat, we need first to establish a public register of foreign ownership and then all Australians will be in a position to know which of our national assets are in foreign hands. This fundamental information is our right and it is essential to public policy making.

Indeed, the first question I asked in this chamber when I became a senator was about the question of a register for foreign ownership. The then Premier of Western Australia, Mr Brian Burke, made a public statement that there was no need for such a register in Western Australia. When I questioned him to what extent Western Australian assets were foreign owned he said he did not know. Current Premier, Carmen Lawrence, has not made a statement about such a register, but Mr Barry MacKinnon, the leader of the Liberal Party in Western Australia, has indicated publicly that the Liberals would be in favour of a register of foreign ownership for Western Australia.

It is the belief of the Federal Government and the Federal coalition Opposition that increases in foreign investment are necessary to meet the interest bill on our foreign borrowing. Indeed, the corporate debt binge of the mid to late 1980s, which was encouraged by this Government with its negative gearing policy on foreign borrowings, is now resulting in a swap of foreign debt for foreign ownership and control. The vast majority of Australians do not welcome this shortsighted economic solution which will lead only to long-term problems in the shape of future payments of rent, profits and dividends to overseas owners, and it will significantly reduce the control which future Australian governments will be able to exercise over our economic situation and well-being.

Currently, approval for 100 per cent foreign ownership in the service industry real estate category is given unless the Treasurer judges the proposal to be contrary to the national interest. Many real estate investments do not have to come before the FIRB at all. Purchases of rural property worth less than $3m and businesses worth less than $5m have been exempt from FIRB approval since 1987. Purchases of several adjoining properties each worth less than $3m can result in enormous areas of rural land passing into foreign hands and the well-being of whole Australian communities can come to depend on the whims of absentee landlords. This is a particular concern in Western Australia and in Queensland.

When on 30 April 1987 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the changes I just mentioned, he forecast that they would reduce applications needing FIRB consideration from 1,300 to 400 annually, but what he did not forecast and what has transpired is that the easing of the approvals procedure has been followed by a substantial sell-off of Australian assets without substantial benefits to the Australian economy.

Mr Keating's forecast of 400 applications annually needing FIRB consideration looks very sick today in the light of the most recent statistics. In its 1988-89 report, the FIRB reports how it considered 5,163 applications for foreign purchases of Australian assets, 4,398 of which it approved. Another 688 were withdrawn or approved automatically; only 77 were refused. I repeat: of 5,163 applications received, only 77 were refused.

Various sections in the community, including the National Farmers Federation, have expressed concern about the acquisition of rural properties and pastoral leases and the possibility of vertically integrated industries controlled by foreign interests; that is, not only the land, but also the transport, abattoirs, and the processing-the whole show. Foreign ownership has implications for virtually every facet of the Australian economy. Foreign investment occurs in the banking sector, the timber industry, the food and drink industry, tourism, recreation, mining, fishing, residential and commercial sectors and the media. My Australian Democrats colleague Senator Powell yesterday introduced into the Senate a private member's Bill to limit foreign ownership of television broadcasting stations to a maximum of 20 per cent.

The banking industry is a good example. The current Government broke with a long established tradition by admitting foreign banks into Australia. The Australian Democrats strongly opposed that decision. However, it was supported by the Liberal and National Party senators in this place. The Government claimed that there would be all sorts of major advantages for Australians. It made statements such as that banking would become more competitive, customers would receive a wider range of services and better services, and that the sleepy Australian banking industry would be stimulated by the new competition and would become more efficient.

But it is now possible to assess the success, or otherwise, of the Government's initiative in allowing foreign banks into Australia. Essentially, the result is a disaster-at least for the ordinary people of Australia. I also remind the Senate that it is alleged that, under pressure to maintain profits in a new competitive environment, banks have, on occasion, cut corners, betrayed their fiduciary duty to customers and trapped clients-especially small business people-in excessive levels of debt, and stripped some clients of their assets.

My colleague Senator Paul McLean has repeatedly called in this chamber for an inquiry into banking in this country. Only yesterday he reminded the Senate that he had tabled examples of banks that had foreclosed on the assets of small business people and then sold them at 25 per cent of the valuation they had arrived at when they induced the business people to take the credit-or debt as Senator McLean called it. In come cases that happened fewer than 12 months after their original transaction with the banks.

It is also informative to note that in 1983 when this Government came to power, and before it launched into its deregulation of the financial sector, the percentage of our foreign debt owed by all financial institutions was 11.4 per cent. The percentage owed by the banks as a subset of all financial institutions was 4.1 per cent. By 1989, the percentage owed by all financial institutions had swollen to 33 per cent and that of the banks to 19.2 per cent. Thus during a period of six years the banks' percentage of our debt multiplied five-fold. During the same period their share of the debt of all financial institutions grew from around one-third of the total amount to almost two-thirds, thus opening the door to foreign investment and participation in our economy. This has contributed to the massive blow-out of our foreign debt.

I will now give the Senate some examples from my home State of Western Australia perceived foreign ownership and of who protested-sometimes vainly-against foreign ownership. One group in Western Australia which has expressed deep concern is the crayfishing industry. That industry was greatly concerned about a proposal last year which would have given a foreign-owned company a 25 per cent share of Western Australia's crayfishing processing licences. It quite rightly feared that foreign-owned processors would discriminate against Australian-owned producers. This would result in sales and profits flowing back to overseas interests, takeovers of vessels and Australian-owned fishing businesses, loss of profitability and viability of Australian businesses and possible manipulation of the market.

Indeed, more than 250 crayfishermen gathered in Geraldton for an angry meeting in January 1989. In February 1989 a delegation led by the Western Australian Fishing Industry Council (Inc.) met with Mr Keating in Canberra. Mr Keating then stated that he believed it would be against the national interest for the Western Australian crayfish industry to be 25 per cent foreign owned.

West Australians were also appalled when they learned that tourism developments on Rottnest Island were being considered for sale to foreign interests. The angry reaction in Perth to the proposed sale of leisure facilities at Rottnest intensified after it became known that the intended purchaser was a subsidiary of the Japanese sports group, Victoria Company Limited. It happens that the Victoria Company is offering $303m for the purpose of the Burswood Island Casino and is also offering to buy out Mr Dallas Dempster's share in the Burswood Property Trust for $93m. Interestingly, Mr Dallas Dempster is also Chairman of the Rottnest Island Authority-a State Government statutory authority.

These are the sorts of circles that we have in Western Australia and it is part and parcel of WA Inc. The connection between the interests of Mr Dallas Dempster and the Victoria Company can no longer be ignored. The company already owns restaurants in Perth and a chain of gift shops with the insultingly inappropriate name, Purely Australian. If the FIRB had wider powers I believe that a full and public investigation conducted into the proposed sell-off of the Burswood Casino facilities would have been very much in the public interest and would have revealed the sensitive issues involved in the ownership of these assets.

If the foreign ownership register, which this Bill seeks to establish, is put in place it would be possible to ascertain what other Australian assets are owned by this company and what the ramifications are. A register of foreign ownership would also reveal the level of foreign ownership of mineral sands industries in Western Australia and elsewhere in Australia. This is a rapidly burgeoning industry in the south-west of Western Australia which is laying siege to many environmentally sensitive areas and threatening the social fabric of established rural communities.

A recent study case could be the sale of assets worth $550m by Pioneer International Ltd, including mineral sands mines in the south-west of Western Australia, which have been operating as Cable Sands (WA) Pty Ltd. An alarming aspect is that a proposed, highly controversial, cable sand mine at Jangardup on the south coast of Western Australia was assessed by the FIRB as a current mine. According to the FIRB guidelines, the sale of a currently operating mine does not require approval. I will quote from a letter from Mr J. F. Livermore, Acting First Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, of 18 January 1990. It states:
The Government's foreign investment policy differentiates between existing developed mines, exploration rights and new mines for development.
The proposal for Nissho to acquire the Pioneer assets was primarily viewed as the takeover of an existing mining business and was examined on that basis.
Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to table that letter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This view is not shared by many Western Australians who are aware that the proposed Jangardup mine is certainly not an existing mine and that it has, in fact, not yet received final approval.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the colonial takeover of much of Asia and Africa by the European powers in the seventeenth, eighteenth and nineteenth centuries was, in most cases, powered initially by foreign investment. Merchants established trading posts and acquired land, wealth and economic power. By patronage and manipulation they stealthily translated this into political influence and political power. When the local people woke up to what was going on and became perturbed and restless, the Europeans called in the military power of their country of origin to protect their, by now extensive, interests. Thus did mighty India with her enormous population and vast resources slip, with barely a whimper, beneath the British yoke. Thus did the textile merchants of Lancashire grow fat on cotton grown in Indian soil by Indian labour.

The mechanisms today may be slightly more subtle but they are potentially, in essence, the same. Force of arms will probably not be needed. Economic takeovers are less bloody and less disruptive to profits. But the ultimate loss of power and control over one's own destiny can be just as complete and just as devastating. Despite the big increase in foreign ownership in Australia, which is evident from the figures in the FIRB annual report of 1988-89, no-one knows its full extent. At present there is no way of finding out precisely how much of Australia has been sold, leased, loaned, mortgaged, or simply given away. I remind the Senate that in 1987 the Premier of Western Australia, Premier Burke, is on record as having stated that he did not know how much of Western Australia was foreign owned.

The establishment of a register of foreign interests which own or control Australian assets is a simple but necessary aid to the economic well-being of Australia. Such a register would require foreign corporations to provide annual returns to the Treasury. Once we gain a comprehensive picture of foreign ownership in Australia we will be in a position to assess possible economic risks and threats to our national sovereignty and to take steps to exercise control in areas where this is shown to be necessary.

The establishment of a register will need to be complemented by an increase in the powers and resources of the FIRB. Indeed, in 1988 the United States House of Representatives debated and passed a Bill to establish such a register of foreign ownership of assets and land in the United States. So if the mighty United States economy, the most powerful on the Earth, can be threatened by foreign ownership, how much more vulnerable are we in Australia to this threat? If I had time, I would read to the Senate part of the debate on that particular Bill.

It is a characteristic of banana republics that they allow foreign ownership to flourish without control, their limited resources to fall into the hands of foreigners, and their labour to be exploited for the benefit of those same interests. If we are to avoid sliding downhill into banana republic status, we need desperately to know who owns what. At present no-one knows the extent of foreign ownership in Australia. When there is no knowledge, there is rumour and speculation. I commend this urgency motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be wonderful for the Australian Democrats to come into the Senate with no aspirations ever to govern the country, to have no responsibilities for the things they advocate because they know they will never have to implement them. It is even more easy when one, in particular, knows she is not going to be here much longer. They do not have to consider priorities. They do not have to worry whether what they are doing is more important then the hundred other things they would like to do-they just say that we should do them all. Then they come up and say they are all urgent. This is an urgency motion. It is a wonderful matter of urgency. Senator Jenkins said they proposed it in 1984. The senator who proposed it lost his seat. It was again proposed in 1989, and the senator who proposed it lost her seat. I hope it is not contagious.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter is not in any sense urgent. The first thing that we want to comment on about this motion is that it is supposedly an urgency motion. We can talk about the merits of it in a moment. Firstly, I just want to say whatever definition of urgency Senator Jenkins might have, this is a blatant misuse of the Standing Orders of the Senate. She pretends that something that may or may not be a good idea-depending upon one's view of the merits-is, six years after it was originally proposed, paralysingly, urgent, when we all know that it is not. The failure to distinguish between the important and the urgent is one of the problems that besets people who do not have to set priorities and who never aspire to govern.

Why do we think this motion is being put? Everybody knows why, but let me just put it on the record for any poor benighted soul who might read this bit of Hansard. It is because the Australian Democrats need to get their division numbers up. They need a few divisions where they vote against everybody else. So they say, `What is the silliest idea we can think of that anybody who might ever have to govern the country would not agree with?' They dream it up not as a matter of public importance but as an urgency motion so we have to have a vote. Then they get their division numbers up. It is a bit pathetic.

I am delighted to join the debate, I just resent being told this artificial proposal pretending that something is urgent has to be dragged before the Senate when we have so much other important work to do.

Let us talk about foreign investment and let us talk about whether we ought to have a register, its costs and its benefits. The debate about foreign investment is an important one. I have to say it was not advanced very substantially by the comments we just heard, nevertheless the fact that people can say unimportant things about it does not mean it is not an important question. There is an important question of balance.

The things Senator Jenkins said are not entirely without merit. The conclusions to which she took us are quite erroneous, but it does not mean there is no reasonable cause for concern for the legitimate interests of Australians about foreign investment in Australia. There needs to be a balance between the benefits which foreign investment brings to Australia and the rights of Australians to have the final say over the nature of that investment and over the way in which the economy develops. I think that balance is important. It is the theme to which I wish to return on several occasions during this discussion, because although I think the Democrats have got it wrong, I certainly think the Opposition's proposals in the last election were equally ill-founded. So we need to talk about that question of balance. Let us talk about the Democrats' proposal first and then about the alternatives, should time permit.

What sort of cost benefit analysis does one apply to this proposal? At the end of the day that is what we need to decide, not ask what is the total aggregate of good ideas that might be in the world that we could introduce if only there were enough resources. We need to know what are the benefits of doing this against the costs of doing it, without looking at the ultimate question-which we do not have time for-which is what are the alternative things we could do with these resources. So what are the potential benefits?

After we have a register, nothing actually happens. It is not like saying that we are going to strengthen the FIRB. Maybe we can declare it a national monument and everybody can come and look at it-it will become a tourist attraction-because it is an after the event register. What it says is 17 things happened last year which we wish had not happened. It is not an action; it simply provides a record of what has happened. What are we going to do with it? When one starts looking at costs and benefits, the register does not get to the crux of the problems. There are issues to be looked at in foreign investment, but a register is not the solution. I am not pretending that this is the Democrats' intention, although others might say so, but the unintentional consequence of what it would do would be the release and exacerbation of the xenophobic pressures which can always build up in a country, particularly in time of economic adversity.

There is a significant downside that needs to be looked at. I think foreign investment needs to be looked at in a very non-discriminatory manner. I want to reiterate, because someone on the other side of the chamber seemed to be concerned about it, that I am not alleging that as the motivation of the honourable senators who put forward the proposal; I am simply saying we have to look at the unintended consequences of things that happen as well as the intent of the people who proposed them. Many dreadful things have happened, caused by people acting with the best of intentions. The thing about it is that we do know the position. It is not as if governments have been unable to act in areas of foreign investment where they have been concerned.

This is a very strange day to initiate this proposal. Yesterday the Australian Government announced actions to make strict limits on foreign ownership in a very important strategic area of our interest-not so much important economically, but important culturally; it is important to the preservation of the Australian culture. The day after that proposal we did not need a register to find out there was a problem-that information was available. We were able to find it and we were able to know what policy we wanted and to act. Most other countries have acted in similar ways without such a register.

We talk about the problems that people perceived in 1987. The Government acted in 1987 on the question of the ownership of residential land. We did not need a register to tell us that there was a problem. We did not all need to sit down and say, `It has gone from 11.2 to 13.9 per cent'. Sufficient information was available for the Government to act when it believed it was necessary to act in the national interest. What we need is a Government with the will to act and the capacity to protect the national interest when required, and that will and capacity has been exhibited. We can have a perfectly legitimate debate about whether there is too much control or not enough, but it does not need some sort of register. There are already reviews made of a wide range of areas of foreign investment proposals. They come before the FIRB. Some people might wish more of them were rejected; some people might wish more of them were allowed and none were rejected, but we certainly get plenty of information.

What are the costs? Trying to find the benefits, I must admit, is a bit like looking for a needle in a haystack. There are public direct costs. The Commonwealth Government at the moment in the main has no record of these transactions. They are not transactions conducted under Commonwealth jurisdiction; they are records conducted under State jurisdiction. We have land registers. We have corporate affairs commissions and we have one thing that is increasingly coming under Federal jurisdiction-the Australian Stock Exchange. Essentially they are where these records are kept, but predominantly they are not matters of Commonwealth responsibility.

The first thing I say about that is that, if there are to be such registers, I think they ought to be set up by the States. I do not want to go along that tangent. My colleague Senator Schacht might wish to pursue it subsequently. There would be significant direct public cost in establishing the very large record-keeping proposal. Nobody has yet effectively costed it because the cost of costing makes it not worth doing also. It is quite clear that we do not need a major survey to work out that we are talking about a significant bureaucratic task in establishing the records, establishing liaison with the States, getting the information from the States, and maintaining and reviewing the information regularly-that is, were we to get the cooperation of the States for the proposal. I have to say that the track record in that area is not fantastic.

For some years we have been trying to set up the Australian Securities Commission. Even after we get every State government to agree, we still cannot guarantee to get the legislation passed because the reprobates in the Legislative Council of Western Australia will not pass it. They still think they are living in the nineteenth century. I would love to have a debate about that some time. They are living under electoral rules that protect them as though they were living in the nineteenth century; but we will debate that at another time. It is an appalling decision. In a situation where five State governments in Australia do not control the upper Houses in their States, we may well find that, even if the Federal Government has the will, it does not have the capacity to set up this register.

There are private direct costs. Every foreign company and every individual who comes from overseas to do business in Australia would find that process more expensive because they would have to set up extra bureaucratic functions and extra reporting services and would have to keep extra records, et cetera. It makes Australia a less attractive place in which to do business.

There are also substantial indirect costs. There are a number, but I want to refer to only one: it would send absolutely the wrong signal to people around the world about Australia's attitude to foreign investment. Australia needs, has always needed and continues to need foreign investment. Since 1788 Australia has always had foreign investment. Actually, there is an interesting historical argument about whether we had some before then. But let us not worry about that. Australia is a very small country with very large capital requirements.

If we are not to have that foreign investment, how will we supply the jobs to Australians? We will otherwise be trying to invest solely upon the basis of the inadequate savings of Australians or we will have Australian companies borrowing money overseas so that they can tap into the savings of other countries to invest in Australia and thus create the jobs, with the debt consequences that follow. I have to say that the balance to which I referred before is a very difficult one to strike. It is true that we want to maintain a high level of investment in Australia if we are to sustain growth and keep providing jobs to Australians. The Opposition, in its policies at the last election, was recommending a virtual open slather. At page 21 of the Economic Action Plan, the Opposition said:
These controls-
that is, controls on foreign investment-
should be abolished except for certain strategic areas as the media, and with them the Foreign Investment Review Board.

The whole box and dice was to go. I am not actually sure that that was the policy of the Opposition, because a few days later the National Party of Australia put out an election policy statement which on page 29 stated:
We will ensure there is a more effective review and monitoring of foreign investment in Australian enterprises.

No wonder all the National Party senators have left the chamber. They probably wanted to vote for this motion and were not allowed to. That is why they have left. Their policy says that they want to have more effective review and monitoring. Senator Jenkins should have been liaising with Senator Boswell. He might have been onside with her, for the first time. I am not quite sure what the Opposition's policy was. If we assume that we should attribute the Opposition's policy to the Economic Action Plan, I say that it fundamentally got the balance wrong. My view is reinforced by the Opposition's reaction to yesterday's decision concerning television ownership. I think Opposition members are quite wrong about that. I think they have the principles wrong. They have the balance wrong.

Australians have a very broad understanding of the role which foreign investment can play and has played in Australian development over the last 200 years. They are aware that we need the extra investment to generate our growth. They are aware that benefits flow from foreign investment in terms of access to technology. They are aware that it potentially gives greater benefit to markets, that international companies coming to operate in Australia are much more likely to be export orientated and that we are much more likely to get access to the markets of their host countries when there are investments developed from companies from those countries.

Fundamentally, we are saying that Australia needs to be internationalising the Australian economy-not trying to wrap it in cotton wool but opening it to the world, saying `We are prepared to compete; we are prepared to go out and take the world on in terms of trying to provide efficiency, trying to be competitive, trying to be open'. Therefore, we need to continue to encourage Australian companies to extend their operations internationally where it is appropriate and in their interests and to have others invest here. It is necessary; it is inevitable anyway. We could not prevent it if we wanted to-unless we want to model ourselves on the Burmese economy. The modern industrial world, the modern financial world, is a 24-hour a day high-tech immediate communication world. We have to be open to that sort of investment. I think the balance is important and it is difficult to strike.

I reiterate that it would be an extremely expensive exercise for the Commonwealth Government to set up such a register. It sound easy but it would be very difficult. At the moment there are no records upon which the register can be based at the Commonwealth level. It would require extensive new reporting mechanisms. I am not sure whether doing it annually is a particularly useful exercise anyway. In these days of modern computers, this is a bit of a quill pen suggestion. If we were going to do it, we would want it to be a contemporaneous record. Nearly all those records are computerised. We would need to maintain those contemporaneous records, but that is a very expensive task. If it is to be useful, we need to get the information at a time when it is useful, not much later. There would be substantial public costs. There would be substantial private costs. There is substantial net detriment to the Australian economy. It would be sending the wrong signals to the world about the way in which we want our economy to operate.

The Australian Government already can act, and proved yesterday that it is prepared to act, when it believes the situation requires such action. The information we require on which to act in those areas is substantially already available, but is assisted by the occasional Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys. They are much more likely to be a useful source of information on which to base policy than is a necessarily imperfect and after the event register. Even were it to be cost effective and done perfectly, it is highly unlikely to be a very useful document.

We do not want to send the wrong signals to the rest of the world. We want to maintain our commitment and our momentum to internationalise the economy. I agree that it is important that we talk about the matter because there is a delicate balance to be maintained between the need for foreign investment and the right to control our own destiny. That balance, I think, is being struck. We need to continue to talk about it. I do not believe a register makes any contribution to that and I urge the Senate to reject the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my belief that the call for a register of foreign ownership in Australia is an emotional and, maybe at this stage, a dangerous diversion away from the very serious economic problems confronting this country. They are problems which are the direct result of seven years of Labor mismanagement. I thought it was appalling that in the response that Senator McMullan gave to what Senator Jenkins believes is a matter of urgency he handled the matter in a very light way. There is emotional concern among the general public and the reason for that concern is not recognised. How did we get to that stage? We got to that stage because our economy has been allowed to get into the situation that we are in.

SPEECH.PARA: The single most important and serious problem for this country is the chronic current account deficit-a fact mentioned by Senator Walsh in recent times. The fact is that month in and month out, year in and year out we import more than we export. As a result, our net foreign debt had increased under seven years of Labor from some $30 billion-odd to $118 billion at the last count. When we buy more than we sell there are only two ways to pay for that deficit. Both involve the savings of foreigners. We either borrow the savings of foreigners or we encourage the savings of those same foreigners into investment in Australia. It is the latter which must be encouraged at this stage.

The problem with the Australian Democrats' motion is that it positively discourages foreign investment and it puts out a signal of uncertainty about the future of that investment. While a lot of people say that that could not happen in Australia, a lot of foreign investors in South American-type countries-honourable senators might recall the Treasurer, Mr Keating, talking about our going down the Argentinean road-have seen assets seized. It is the wrong signal to give at a time of almost economic crisis in this country. Prior to 1983, I would have favoured debt rather than equity participation. Prior to coming into this place I put that statement on the record. My reasoning for it, in those days, was that, if one had the capacity to repay the debt, in time one would have total ownership of the particular asset concerned. The sad reflection on this country is that today that is not an option. We must seek equity investment from overseas. Debt must be serviced, irrespective of the profitability of a particular organisation.

In these disastrous economic conditions this can often mean that an overseas lender can acquire, sometimes unwillingly, an Australian asset by default. I give a current classic example of the Bond University. No Australian buyer can be found for the Bond share of this particular institution. I understand that over the last couple of years it has been totally funded by the Japanese partner. What may well happen is that the Japanese partner will become the reluctant owner of 100 per cent of Bond University. With this sort of build-up and antagonism towards foreign ownership, I can tell the Senate what the headlines will be: `Japanese own and control Australia's only private university'. Shock, horror! Yet it may be the only option-not because the Japanese particularly want to do so but because there is no option. With equity investment, foreign investors take their chances. If they succeed, they get a return; if the investment suffers a loss, they must pay their share of the loss. I do not believe that the Australian Democrats can have it both ways.

For the last three years I have sat here and listened to the Democrats railing about the level of overseas borrowings. We heard former Senator Haines complaining-demanding, in fact-that interest on overseas loans should not attract a tax deduction. As I indicated earlier, if we have this continuing deficit between what we buy from overseas and what we sell, when imports continue to exceed exports, we have no option but to take one of those two courses. We do have some options, of course, to overcome the need for such massive foreign investment. One option is to export more and import less and engage in more local manufacture of consumption goods. By that, I mean making the things that people want to buy. We have to ask ourselves a lot of questions. Of our exports, over 80 per cent comprise minerals and primary products-commodities.

With the current slump of our second largest export earner, wool, our position is looking more and more desperate. I would rather use the word `desperate' than the word `serious' which was used by Senator Button and for which he was savaged by the Treasurer. When I saw the savaging by the Treasurer, I wondered whether his incredible reaction related to his sensitivity to the role that Senator Button played when he had the job of messenger to bring the bad news to Mr Hayden in 1983. Perhaps Mr Keating saw Senator Button in this instance as being once again the messenger-this time, however, somewhat more subtly.

The outlook for exports is decidedly gloomy, and it gives me no pleasure to say that. Not only is there trouble with wool, but the price for steaming coal has gone soft, with prices reduced by over $5 a tonne. I remind the Senate that coal is our largest export earner. A part solution to our problem is to lift the level of processing of our raw materials prior to export-what is commonly called value added. The point I make is that, if that were profitable, it would already be happening. The reason why it is not happening is the sort of question that should be addressed.

Factors acting against value added are numerous. We can ask overseas investors why they do not go into this. One of the complaints made-I think this is what Senator Jenkins was referring to-is that the sort of foreign investment we are getting is coming into areas that people do not like. They are saying, `Why can't they go into areas which give us more value added, in raw materials or import replacements?'. One will always get the same answer when one asks those potential overseas investors this question: `Why are you putting 16 golf courses on the Gold Coast in Queensland? Why aren't you making something that replaces imports? Why aren't you making television sets and so on?'. The answer is always the same: we have an inflexible industrial relations system with entrenched restrictive work practices, which make our unit costs of production uncompetitive. It has nothing to do with wages. It is an entrenched system and it is endemic throughout Australia. It does not matter what institution one goes to, one will see it. I ask that, some time down the track, the Democrats bear that in mind when we start looking at freeing up the industrial market.

We have a grossly inefficient transport system and a waterfront which is a scandal-not only in respect of cost but because of its notorious unreliability. It has been said to me on many occasions that people would not mind the cost if they could be assured of reliability. We have a tax system which is not competitive in a competitive world. I say this deliberately, because these were the factors which prompted the China Steel company to decide to put its steel plant into Malaysia rather than into Gladstone. Gladstone is a major coal outlet for Queensland. The opportunity to use our coal to process steel with iron ore from the Pilbara for export may never come again. It is another opportunity lost. This was brushed off by Senator Button in Question Time yesterday when he simply should have said, `We could not compete'. Malaysia offered better prospects than Australia. It was a better place to invest some $US2 billion. What a sorry state this country has got itself into.

Another obvious solution is to engage in the manufacture of import replacement goods; we should make the consumption goods that people want to buy. If it were possible, this area could be taken up by small to medium business. But it is not happening. Why not? With interest rates running at about 20 per cent-three times more than our overseas competitors-it is absolutely impossible for a legitimate business to survive. The majority of businesses do not have access to equity financing; their only option is borrowing.

I could not believe the remarks made in this chamber yesterday by Senator Button about the many small business failures. I think these are the words he used: `Thousands of small businesses were in this position because their owners and managers were inexperienced and should not have gone into business'. I find that an incredible remark. It is a sign that a government has lost touch; it has its head in the sand.

I telephoned a couple of banks this morning. We are sitting on a volcano. These are direct remarks made by bank authorities-not people with an axe to grind but genuine remarks made by people I have known for some time. In the past a person with difficulties-whether he ran a business or owned a home-would communicate with his bank. For example, if he had to pay about $1,000 a month to the bank-I am just pulling that figure out of the hat-he would say, `I have some difficulties. Can we make a deal?' The bank would accommodate him and maybe say, `Let's make it $100 a month. How will you go with that?' and he would accept it.

That position has changed. They are not communicating. In fact, the banks are taking a different view. Telephone calls are not being responded to and letters are not being replied to. In some cases, this is forcing foreclosures. People are not able to cope.

People such as Nobby Clark are trying their best to give signals. But, as I understand it, they are reluctant to spell out the detail of the disaster because they do not wish to exacerbate an already disastrous position. In other words, they do not wish to precipitate panic. In addition, we have the entrenched restrictive work practices and an inflation rate of 8.7 per cent-double that of our trading partners-which, with the passage of time, guarantees the destruction of any competitive edge which a business might have had at the time of its establishment.

I also add that-this is something that has not been considered-an inflation rate double that our trading partners will eventually ensure the destruction of our established markets for our minerals and primary products. No-one considers that. They think we can go on forever with an inflation rate of 8.7 per cent exporting those products to the world. Overseas buyers in the balanced markets-over long periods we do get balanced markets-will not pay any increase greater than their own inflation rate. That must always be remembered. With the inflation rate of our major trading partner running at between one per cent and 2 per cent or thereabouts-it has been that for the past decade or so-and ours at 8.7 per cent, one does not have to be a mathematical wizard to recognise the seriousness of the problem. They are saying, `We will not import your inflation'.

What has the Government done to address the structural problems? First, it will not deregulate the labour market. The Australian Council of Trade Unions is hell bent on increasing its power base and the Australian Labor Party is its political arm. Second, there has been no micro-economic reform except in the deregulation of the financial markets, which happened very early in the piece. Senator Collins has bravely given the Labor Government 12 months notice of resignation in this regard. I congratulate him for that.
