My concern about the Democrats' urgency motion is that it is geared to inflame the emotions of nationalistic Australians, of whom I am unashamedly one. We must be very careful about this. I know that it is not intentional, but it also smacks of racism. I will not go into that. Both these factors serve only to frighten foreign investment which regrettably we badly need, away from Australia. My State of Queensland, which has been the centre of great foreign investment, has a foreign registry. What happened after the books were closed? The headline came out: Queensland `1pc foreign-owned'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating an urgency motion put by Senator Jenkins. It calls for the establishment of a register of foreign ownership to register and keep track of certain classes of foreign ownership. Senator McMullan said that because we had raised this issue on a number of previous occasions, it was therefore not of urgency. We argue on the contrary: precisely because the Government and the Opposition have consistently refused to accept our arguments for the establishment of such a register, the matter becomes more and more urgent as time goes on and as this country passes more and more into the hands of foreign owners.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, we could parallel this with a patient with a pimple on his face who turns up to see a doctor. The patient might say, `This is not a particularly urgent matter. I will simply treat it with some hot compresses and it will go away'. The doctor recognises that it has the potential to become a very urgent problem. The patient ignores the doctor's advice and goes away.

Within a few days the patient has meningitis because of the infection travelling inside the skull. As the patient approaches death the problem becomes more and more urgent. The fact that some days earlier the doctor signalled that this was an urgent problem does not in any way deny its urgency; in fact, it confirms that the doctor was right in the first place. So the Australian Democrats were correct when raising this matter some years ago by way of a private member's Bill-and we are correct today.

There is a point to what Senator McMullan was saying. At this stage we are calling for a register. We clearly recognise that as the first necessary and essential step to knowing exactly what level of foreign ownership we have in what areas. We would then move on from that to more properly monitor and control that ownership so that it did not lead to the condition with which Senator Jenkins concluded her speech-the loss of control over our own destiny. That is what we are really on about.

I was disappointed to hear both Senator McMullan and Senator Parer suggest that by raising this issue we were raising the level of xenophobia or racism. I think that Senator Jenkins was quite clear in saying that we are not concerned whether it is foreign ownership by Germans, French, Japanese or anybody else; it concerns people who are not nationals of this country and who therefore owe a primary allegiance to another country. That is the question, particularly when the level of foreign ownership is quite considerable.

When one looks at the levels of foreign ownership-Senator Parer has mentioned that Queensland has established a register-one sees that in the six months April to September 1989 Japanese investors poured $2.3 billion into Australia. Interestingly, that figure did not come from Australian sources because we did not know; that figure was taken from the Japanese Ministry of Finance. The Japanese Ministry of Finance keeps those figures. Senator McMullan was wrong when he said that most foreign countries do not keep such registers. The truth is that most countries do keep registers. Australia is the odd nation out.

The number of proposals for investment in Australia has been mentioned by Senator Jenkins but it is worth repeating because it underscores the weakness of the control which is currently exercised in this country. She pointed out that in 1988-89 there were 5,163 proposals for investments in Australia, only 77 of which were rejected.

Interestingly, when one looks at the sectors into which the investment passed, those which recorded strongest growth in total expected investment were tourism and-wait for it-real estate. Quite contrary to what Senator Parer was trying to claim-that is, that foreign investment is going into some sort of productive investment which is going to relieve our foreign indebtedness-large amounts of foreign investment at the moment are going into real estate and speculation.

Indeed, if one turns to Senator Parer's own State, one finds that Mr Parker of Burchill Bate Parker, speaking of the activity of foreign investors in Queensland, is quoted in an article in the Australian of 2 December 1989 as saying:
. . . many of the integrated resort entrepreneurs sought large parcels of land, obtained rezoning approvals for an integrated resort, and then sought partners or investors or simply sold the land.

That is precisely what is going on extensively not only in Queensland but also in other States, particularly in Western Australia where there is massive speculation in Australian real estate of no benefit to this country whatsoever. In fact, it mitigates very much against the purchase of real estate by Australian nationals because it is simply another instrument entering the market. I point out that Australians wanting to borrow money in Australia to buy Australian real estate, say, for building a home or some quite legitimate purpose, face particularly high interest rates, as Senator Parer correctly pointed out. A Japanese person wanting to buy Australian real estate to speculate against that Australian purchaser can borrow money at low interest rates and afford to hold on to the land for a long time. That sort of investment is directly acting against the interests of Australian home purchasers.

Turning to the rural area, the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council has released a report on the purchase of properties for the raising of livestock. An article in the Australian Financial Review of December 1989 states:
In its report, the Council said that official statistics on foreign investment in rural property were poor, and non-existent for meat processing and feedlots.
Elsewhere in the report of the Council it was strongly recommended that a register be established so that the Council would know exactly what was going on in that area. The article continues:

However, based on industry information, it said Japanese-owned abattoirs in Australia accounted for 23 per cent of beef and veal exports to Japan in the first half of 1989 and 14 per cent of cattle killed for the market.

Current and planned investment in beef feedlot capacity was put at 165,000 head, equal to around 66,000 tonnes of beef exports suitable for Japan, or just under half the current total of 136,000 tonnes.

It further proposed that the board maintain a more detailed record of foreign investment in livestock production and meat processing, and that information collected from both recommendations be published annually.

Further on in its report the Council mentions inter-nation profit shifting. This is what happens when there is vertical integration of an industry such as the beef industry and those who own the farms also own the transport systems, the abattoirs, the ships that take the produce overseas and the wholesaling and retailing facilities in foreign countries. Transfer pricing can easily mean that there will be no benefit whatsoever to the country in which the cattle are raised and the abattoirs are sited. The Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council drew attention to that. The Australian Financial Review article pointed out that the Council said that one of the effects of foreign investment was:
Inter-nation profit shifting, of which there already were strong suggestions, although no hard evidence.
The article continued:
On the latter, the council recommended the Australian Taxation Office explore ways of ensuring effective monitoring of price movements to limit opportunities for profit shifting.

How is the Australian Taxation Office even going to begin to look at this area unless there is a register of foreign ownership, unless it knows which countries it is dealing with are foreign and where the shareholding lies? A Sunday-Mail article of 3 December 1989 states:
PRIME Queensland land is being bought by foreigners at an increasing rate.

At the moment Queensland is the only State that has a register. I point out, in answer to Senator McMullan's claim that the establishment of a register would be costly, that every single land transaction in Australia is currently registered. In the case of South Australia, transactions are registered with a board which keeps that information. All that would be required to establish a register is a statement as to the nationality of the person buying the property at the time of the land transaction. This is not a particularly costly process. The article continues:
The state's foreign land register shows the value of foreign-owned land in Queensland is 30 times higher than when the Sunday Mail last checked the register six months ago.
Last week, the register showed $1553 million worth of land in foreign hands-with more than half the total value owned by the Japanese.
And that figure could be just the tip of the iceberg because foreigners have until April 17 next year-
and that, of course, is this year-
to declare their interests.

Undoubtedly, we have a serious and growing problem in respect of which evidently and, perhaps for slightly different reasons-but that is not particularly relevant here-both the Government and the Opposition turn their backs. They do not even want to know the extent of foreign ownership let alone do anything about it.

Senator Jenkins drew attention to some of the history of economic trading which led ultimately to total foreign ownership during the seventeenth, eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. I would like to look at what has happened in this country. Just last year we dealt with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation. We have debated extensively the prior ownership and occupation of this country by Aboriginal people, a people who had no sense of land ownership as we see it. They belonged to the land. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) attempted to insert into the ATSIC legislation a preamble which said, among other things:
And whereas the people whose descendants are now known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia were the prior occupiers and original owners of this land;
And whereas they were dispossessed by subsequent European occupation and have no recognised rights overland yet recognised by the Courts other than those granted or recognised by the Crown;
And whereas that dispossession occurred without compensation and no serious attempt was made to reach a lasting and equitable agreement with them on the use of their land;

And whereas it is the intention of the people of Australia to make provision for rectification . . . to ensure for all time that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples receive that full recognition and status within the Australian nation to which history, their prior ownership and occupation of the land, and their rich and diverse culture, fully entitle them to aspire;

What hypocrisy! This Government not only displaces those people and replaces that attitude of belonging to the land with one in which land simply becomes a commodity to be traded, brought and sold, but also it proceeds to sell off that land as hard as it can lick to foreign interests. At the same time as it does this, it claims that it wants to enter into an instrument of reconciliation with those same Aboriginal people which will recognise that culture, that prior occupation and that prior ownership. What hypocrisy!

A number of other matters were dealt with, but let me raise the matter of the Torrens Island power station in South Australia. This power station was built by the Electricity Trust of South Australia. It has been sold by the Government of South Australia to foreign interests and then leased back in a way in which the people of South Australia cannot even find out who owns the principal power station which generates their electricity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also ask the question: where is the urgency in this motion? This matter can be regarded as urgent only because Senator Jenkins wants to make it urgent before she moves out of here. She has only got this week and next week to go. It is simply so that Senator Jenkins before she departs, and the Australian Democrats, can feel good about something. They will feel they have achieved something if they speak about this matter, let alone have the motion agreed to. As has already been pointed out by other speakers, this motion is simply a tabulation of what is already known. As one honourable senator has already said, this information is available in titles offices around Australia. One probably has only to put in the right code, hit a button and one has all the information one wants.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to the Foreign Investment Review Board. Incidentally, I should correct what Senator McMullan said about our policy in the last election campaign. Our policy was to do away with the Foreign Investment Review Board, but if Senator McMullan had read on a little further he would have discovered that we were going to put it in the hands of Treasury. He failed to point that out, so I take the opportunity to do so. I believe the Foreign Investment Review Board has always worked from the wrong end. If the problems the Democrats are worried about were apparent, they should have been addressed by the Foreign Investment Review Board looking at properties valued up to $2m or $3m, rather than the more expensive ones. In any event, the smaller landowners the Democrats worry about could not compete in that market.

I will be directing my remarks in this debate to the foreign ownership of land in the agricultural sector. I quote from the report of the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council on foreign investment in rural properties, which is the same report Senator Coulter quoted from. That report says:

Statistics from FIRB indicate that there were only 14 proposals by foreigners to purchase rural land valued at over $3m in 1987/88. A further 78 proposals were received for property valued at less than $3m.

So there is hardly an avalanche of property going to foreign ownership. Foreign investment in land in Australia is not necessarily a bad thing. No-one is forced to sell land to an overseas buyer. There is no Act of Parliament that says, `You shall sell to a foreign buyer'. Land has to be on the market in the first place and the owner has to be happy with the person to whom he sells the land, whether it is an Australian or an overseas buyer; so no-one is forced to sell. Of course, there is an advantage in having foreign buyers when there are not Australian buyers who are prepared to pay a reasonable price, or any price, for land-and that has happened. When there are buyers of that magnitude during a downturn in the economy, it has a stabilising effect on the market. If a farmer wants to sell out or is forced out, then he can go with some dignity and, more importantly, can get the finance either to start again or go into retirement or whatever he might be doing.

Land bought by overseas interests cannot be shifted overseas; it has to stay in place. The land remains, it produces, it employs extra labour, and it pays local rates and taxes. The land generally goes through a redevelopment stage. I have yet to see a farm bought by overseas interests where there is not a complete or semi-complete development. New fences, buildings and dams create demands for employment and materials. These are all aspects that I personally have taken notice of over quite a number of years. Foreign buyers of land are not interested in all sections of farming areas, or pastoral areas for that matter. Senator Coulter referred to the Aborigines having their land taken from them. What foreign buyer would want to buy the land that Aboriginal communities have been on or are now on in semi-arid desert country? It is important who the buyers are and what sort of land is involved. Americans have generally gone for high rainfall pastoral country; Germans have generally gone for medium to high rainfall sheep country; Japanese have gone for high rainfall coastal country; and the Italians have gone for lower than medium rainfall country. What is more, their activities in land purchases have not all coincided. If the economies of other countries were strong at the same time as Australia's economy and if foreign buyers were all interested in acquiring land in Australia at the same time we may have a problem, but it generally does not work that way. We have had American interests, then Japanese interests, then German and Italian interests, and even English interests, but not all foreign interest comes at once. Of course, the purchase of land by foreign interests is not just happening in Australia; it has happened in many other places.

On the question of farming land, another aspect to consider is that fewer Australians now want to be farmers. If we do not have willing buyers in Australia-bearing in mind that the farms cannot be shifted-what is wrong with selling to foreigners who are willing to produce? Farmers' sons and daughters are now more interested, if they have academic ability, in entering the professions. A good example of that was in the big downturn of 1971 when, for the first time in Victoria, there was a waiting list for admission to university. The reason for that was that more country children were coming through wanting to go to university. Of course, they may have gone back to the country later, but who knows? So reasons exist for land being available to be purchased by foreign owners.

If foreign ownership of land is deemed to be a bad thing, then the only way out is to have a healthy farm balance of trade. That is the only way we can buy back the farms. If a build-up of foreign ownership of land is occurring-and this has happened in the past-a healthier economy is needed in order to buy back the land. Esperance, in Western Australia, in the late 1950s and early 1960s was developed mostly by the Americans. All the Americans have now sold out there. The economy improved in the 1960s and the Americans were bought out and went back to the United States. The Kimberley cattle stations in the 1960s and 1970s were largely owned by American interests. If one were to go up there now one would not find any land owned by an American.

In the late 1970s and early 1980s there was an influx of German money into Western Australia, buying medium to high rainfall sheep country. The Germans did not work the land themselves, but leased it back to the owners who needed capital, or to neighbours. If one went back now one would see that, once again, there is no German ownership in those areas. Once again, the farms have been bought back.

Of course, now the Japanese are in the high rainfall station country, because that is the flavour of the month, or the year. As has been pointed out, they have come here and taken on cattle stations and bought out feedlots, and they are exporting beef back to Japan. But if we are here in another five years time debating this question we will find that they have all gone home. Hopefully, when the economy revives-when we are in government-the farm will be bought back. Then, so many years down the track there will be a phase when others-maybe the Indonesians-invest in farming in Australia. We will go through the same thing where the Democrats-if there are any left in the Senate-will be bringing up the same matters to make themselves feel good. These phases have been part of Australian life probably since 1788, and they will continue for the rest of our days. As I say, the trend can be reversed with better balance of trade figures for Australia. Then we can buy the farm back.

This Government's economic policy has brought the country-and rural industry-to its knees. The agenda has been high interest rates, high inflation and wage rises without an equivalent rise in productivity. The failure to address deregulation of the closed shop industries has prevented our primary industries from competing with overseas competitors.

There has been the deregulation of the wheat industry during the last 12 months, which we accepted in return for a promised deregulation of the waterfront to get costs down, and deregulation of coastal shipping and the labour market. I do not know whether the Government promised to deregulate the labour market. If all these things are not done to bring us back into a competitive position with overseas competitors, we will never be in a position to prevent the overseas ownership of Australian land. That is the only way we can do it.

There is the example of what happens on the waterfront. It takes a container ship roughly 16 hours to turn around in Japan, and in Sydney it takes eight days, at least. The other example is getting fertiliser from the east coast to Western Aus tralia. It costs $50 a tonne, and it also costs $50 a tonne to bring it from Florida. They are examples of what is wrong with the Australian agricultural industry and why it cannot compete with overseas land buyers at the present moment.
In the short time I have left I will quote a few figures that have just been released by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. The document states:

The index of prices received by Australian farmers fell by 1.8 per cent in the March quarter 1990 . . . This decrease, which followed a fall of 2.9 per cent in the previous quarter, resulted mainly from a fall in the prices received for vegetable and fruit crops . . .
It continues:
Crops to register price decreases were potatoes (46.7%) vegetables (20.1%) citrus fruit (7.3%).
Sheep prices have declined for three successive quarters, falling 9.5 per cent in the March quarter 1990.
This is the more important part of the document, which I should quote before my time runs out:

The index of prices paid by farmers increased by 1.0 per cent in the March quarter 1990 following an increase of 0.4 per cent in the previous quarter. Prices paid items to show the largest quarterly increases were fuel (3.6 per cent) . . .

Those are examples which show why foreign would-be owners of land in Australia are able to compete because the Government has not properly controlled the economy in this country. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in this debate my colleague Senator McMullan raised a very pertinent point-I think he hit the nail on the head-about this urgency motion and the fact that the Australian Democrats have to get the score up a bit by having a vote called where they can show that the Government and the Opposition voted against them. They need that for statistical purposes come the next election-even though it is still some three years away-to prove that from time to time they are, supposedly, the only honest people in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I really think what they have put up here today is a charade. Senator McMullan was quite correct-this issue of foreign investment has been the subject of debate in Australia ever since I have been involved in politics at various levels. It does not have to be the subject of an urgency motion today, as though whatever motion the Senate carries today will have a profound effect on foreign investment in Australia. We are only going through the charade of this debate because the Democrats need to add a couple of goals to their scoreboard for political purposes.

First of all, I want to say that after hearing the two Democrats speakers I was waiting to get an explanation of what would be their next course of action if the motion were passed and in the near future a register were set up to establish a list of all the foreign owned land in Australia; all the property, businesses and resources. Both Democrats speakers today gave no indication of where this would lead us, and what would be their proposal.

I think they ought to be a little bit more fair dinkum. If they do have a concern about the present level of foreign ownership in Australia, it is not just a matter of drawing up a register, compiling it and, therefore, getting the statistics-it is what is going to be done with that information. Neither speaker gave any indication of what the Democrats would want to do. One can only surmise that they would propose, in a very general way, that there should be new restrictions placed on foreign investment because Australia's sovereignty was being affected and these evil foreigners were taking over the running of the country.

If that is the best they can come up with-and I can only assume that because they did not give any explanation-it is a pretty appalling effort. They have said that this is so important that we have to have an urgency motion and a vote, without giving any indication of where it would lead. It is typical of the Democrats. I believe it is one reason why Janine Haines did not win the seat of Kingston. In the last 10 days of the campaign we were finally able to hammer home in South Australia just what the strange mix of Democrat policies was, and what would be its effect on the ordinary electors of Kingston. For the first time we actually get exposure to what the Democrats were offering, in a higgledly-piggledy way, and the electorate started to wake up in Kingston. I suspect that had the coverage been given to the Democrats around Australia, their vote would have been a lot less.

Let us look at the question of statistics and figures. I admit to Senator Coulter and Senator Jenkins that I do not claim to be an expert on the issue of foreign investment, but I have perused the last annual report of the Foreign Investment Review Board. There is ample information in it for anybody-whatever his other perspective-to make judgments, in a considered way, about the debate we should have on foreign investment.

The Democrats have been trying to paint the picture here today that we do not know what is going on. They tell us that they want to know the names of particular people who own particular pieces of property. A few years ago in this place when we had the debate about the Australia Card, the Democrats were jumping up and down about infringement of privacy and people's personal affairs. Yet they say that we have to go one step further in this area and list every foreigner individually so that we can chase them down, so that we know who they are-that that information should be available. We all know what that will lead to. It will lead to certain minority groups in our community-unfortunately, only small minority groups-using that as a basis to whip up a xenophobic attitude towards foreigners in this country. I think that would be an appalling outcome. The Democrats' inconsistency is exposed when they argue about the so-called evils of the Australia Card in invading people's privacy. Yet in this area they want to invade people's privacy, name people, have them listed all around Australia in all these areas-not just property and land, but business and resources. The information is overwhelmingly in the FIRB report. If the Democrats think there are still pieces of information missing, let us raise it with the Foreign Investment Review Board and the Bureau of Statistics and get them to put in the information.

Let us look at some of the figures in the annual report of the Foreign Investment Review Board. They show that in 1988-89 foreign investment in Australia was $26.1 billion. They also show-which honourable senators opposite have not mentioned once-that in the same year Australian investment abroad was $10.5 billion. I want to know whether the Australian Democrats oppose Australian investment abroad.

In the last couple of years, as a member of parliamentary delegations, I have had the opportunity to visit the countries of South East Asia and the South Pacific. The one thing that comes through all the time is that they want foreign investment from Australia. They want their standard of living and their economies to improve by getting investment from Australia in various industries-in the tourist industry, in appropriate agricultural development and so on. They do not make any beg pardons about it.

The Democrats say at one level, `We do not want foreign investment in Australia because we think it is evil. We think it will lead to the diminution of our sovereignty'. Yet they are quite willing to give a complete miss to the view that Australia is a significant investor in its own region to the advantage of countries in the region which want it. We have to get an answer from the Australian Democrats about that.

That report mentions that in 1988-89 Australian banks borrowed $8 billion from overseas. That includes Australian-owned banks. I want to know whether the Australian Democrats favour cutting off that $8 billion of borrowings, that foreign money coming into Australia. Let us not beat around the bush. Where did most of that $8 billion that the banks borrowed go? It went to provide consumer credit to ordinary Australians to enable them to buy houses and so on. We would never get a comment out of the Australian Democrats hitting the nail on the head about what they want to do about banks restricting that sort of borrowing because that would affect ordinary Australians. We do not get any of the hard decisions taken by the Democrats in this debate, we just get the waffle and the soft-headed attitude that it is something to do with evil foreigners investing in Australia.

The report lists in a table the total level of foreign investment in Australia in 1987-88-$191 billion. The United States of America is the second largest investor in Australia, with $39 billion. It slipped from being the first in the previous year. The United Kingdom, with $44 billion, is now the largest investor. Japan is the third largest, with $26 billion. Over the last four or five years, Japanese investment, though significant, has increased by roughly the same proportion as investment from the United Kingdom or the United States of America. Many smaller countries have invested in Australia, at much smaller amounts, but probably have shown bigger increases in percentage terms. The underlying current in some of this criticism of foreign investment is directed particularly against the Japanese.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what we said.

—I know it is not what the honourable senator said, but let us not beat around the bush. When we get down to the bottom line of some of this debate around Australia, unfortunately small minority groups argue the foreign investment issue on the basis that it is Japanese investment-not that it is American or British. Yet the Japanese are by no means the biggest investors. In real terms Japan has only about 13 per cent of our country's total investment.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point out an interesting figure in this document. In 1988-89 it was indicated that there would be $32 billion of foreign investment in Australia, although not all spent in one year, 1988-89; it was indicated that some of it would be spent over a period longer than one year. What is interesting is that, if that figure had not been invested in Australia, the current account deficit for the year, which was $18 billion, would probably have been over $40 billion. What would the economic ramifications for Australia be if we had a current account deficit of $40 billion-plus? The dollar would at at about 15c, interest rates would be at 50 per cent and the unemployment rate would be about 15 to 20 per cent.

If those opposite are going to attack foreign investment, let us look at the up side of it. The up side of Australia's present economic situation is that foreign investment means that our current account deficit is a lot better than it would be without it. We have heard nothing from the Democrats, who want to reduce foreign investment, about how they would handle that problem or about what would happen to us if there were a big increase in the current account deficit.

In the few minutes that I have left I want to deal with the issue of whether Australia should have a closed economy or an international economy. Fifteen months ago I visited a country that for 30 years had been the ultimate example of a closed economy. I do not accuse the Democrats of having the same view as General Nie Win in Burma. He had the most xenophobic attitude. That was the reason he survived for 30 years. He played upon the xenophobic attitude of the Burmese people about their being surrounded by enemies, cutting themselves off with the view that they did not need anybody else. In 30 years Burma went from being one of the best economies in South East Asia to being the worst, the biggest basket case of all, because they cut themselves off in every way. If we went to cut ourselves off, we would end up with the same result. The only way this country will improve its economy is to internationalise it, to be involved in trade with other countries. We cannot trade with other countries if we take the attitude that foreign investment either in Australia or out of Australia is inherently evil. If all countries took that attitude we would go back to the sixteenth century and the policies of mercantilism, with all its attributes, such as conflict. It just does not work. There has to be give and take in international trade, in international finance and in international economies.

In my State of South Australia 10 to 12 years ago Chrysler had a car manufacturing plant which by all accounts was a basket case. My colleague Senator Foreman was secretary of the Vehicle Builders Union at the time. One only needs to speak to him, the workers and the employees at Chrysler to find out about the problems that that company had and the fact that it really had no future. A Japanese company, Mitsubishi, bought it, bought out the American partner, and then started what in many cases has been a revolution in industrial relations, investment, new procedures and new management practices in the plant.

So what do we have today? We have a factory whose productivity is up and which is actually exporting cars back to Japan. Anybody who 10 years ago had said that a car factory in Adelaide would export cars to Japan would have been locked up in Parkside. But it is now happening because the Japanese put in the effort with their technology, with their management practices and with better industrial relations and the work force responded with improved productivity. That is a result of foreign investment, not just of money but of ideas.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The debate from the Government and the Opposition has been interesting in parts, but I put it to the Senate that no speaker from the Government or the Opposition has given a valid argument against the setting up of a national register for foreign ownership. I wish to address some of the points made by some of the speakers.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan queried the fact that the Australian Democrats have brought this issue up again today when we brought it up six years earlier. He did not add that in the six years since this matter was first raised by the Democrats in the Senate the overseas debt in this country has increased enormously. Indeed, Senator Parer mentioned that when he spoke.

We have also had from honourable senators from both sides of the chamber some spurious arguments which did not address the issue at all but, I suspect, rather gave everyone here an insight into motivations that there might be when matters for debate are brought up by members on their side of the chamber.

We have stated all along that a register would be a starting point. What is the harm in knowing where we stand? When we try to elicit facts with regard to foreign ownership it is very hard to find them. As Senator Coulter said, each land transaction is registered and therefore it is a simple further step merely to have on the land transaction whether the buyer is an Australian permanent resident or not.

Senator Parer referred to our import-export deficits, the level of our overseas debt, the need for more manufacturing in Australia, the need for more downstream value adding and the need for more import replacement goods. Nobody can argue with any of those facts as stated by Senator Parer or, indeed, with those points he made. But they are nothing at all to do with Australia having a register of foreign ownership. In fact, there were no arguments against that register. Senator Parer also referred to the banking industry and slated the banking industry as it stands at present. If the banking industry is a test case of advantages which are supposed to accrue to the Australian people from deregulation and foreign investment, then all the signs are that those advantages are illusory.

Senator Schacht used a couple of arguments that it was very hard to connect with the motion presently before us. He correctly said that it was material brought forward by the Australian Labor Party which frightened people from voting for Senator Haines so that the Democrats could have gained their first seat in the House of Representatives. He neglected to mention that it was not only the Labor Party but also the Liberal Party which brought material forward deliberately to frighten people, material which was extremely misleading. The costings put out by Senator Walsh on Democrat policies were put out in such a way as to presume that all those policies would be implemented within one year. That is absolute nonsense. No policies brought forward at election time are there to be implemented immediately in 12 months. Those costings also did not take into account Democrat policies which would save a great deal of money.

Senator Schacht also mentioned the Australia Card. The Democrats were against the Australia Card legislation as brought forward in this Parliament. That was a registration of Australian citizens which was not a mere registration but which would have allowed details of Australian citizens to be given to other departments besides the Department of Health, which was responsible for the Australia Card legislation. Senator Schacht said that, if we were against the Australia Card, we should also be against registration of foreign investors. I would say that that is very different. If there is no difference, why do we have an immigration department which screens overseas people before they can come into this country, whether on a permanent or temporary basis? That is a very different matter.

Senator Schacht also raised the question of Australian investment going abroad. He suggested that, in taking the line that we have in advocating a register for foreign ownership in Australia, we are suggesting that Australian investment abroad should be limited. I suggest to Senator Schacht that, when making such statements on a broad basis, he should look at some of the countries which are soliciting Australian investment, countries such as Burma and Indonesia. He would find that it is the elite segments in those countries that are advocating Australian investment. If he asked some of the ordinary people he might find a different story. In fact, the immediate past President of the Philippines, Marcos, was particularly keen on overseas investment in his country-investment by the United States of America and Australia. Yet in these very times the people of the Philippines are resisting overseas investment which would bring them nuclear power in the form of a nuclear power station which they do not want.

At present no-one knows the extent of foreign ownership in Australia. Where there is no knowledge there can be rumour and speculation. We have heard honourable senators here mention xenophobia and hysteria. I put it to the Senate that rumour and speculation, where the degree of foreign ownership is not known, can lead to very genuine hysteria.

A register would provide us with the facts. It would allay any possibility of hysteria and it would make it possible to assess what foreign investment is in our interests and what foreign investment is opposed to our national interest. It is not a case of whether we should have foreign ownership or not. It is a case of how much we have and, in looking at that, how much the people of Australia want and in what areas they want it.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak on the annual report of the Special Investigations Unit for 1989, that is, up to 30 June 1989. It is nearly the end of May 1990 before it has been tabled in this Parliament. That is not altogether the fault of the Director of the Unit, Mr Greenwood, who submitted it to the then Attorney-General, Mr Bowen, in November of 1989, although the actual date in November 1989 is not shown. There seems to have been an extraordinary delay in this report being presented to the Parliament. However, fortunately, some assiduous members of the Opposition who were at the Estimates Committee hearings last Tuesday were able to get information which has helped to repair that omission, and material has been made available in answers to questions which can be seen in the Hansard for Estimates Committee E.

What has transpired, of course, is the continuing increase in the width of the investigation of this Unit. In his report before us Mr Greenwood has given the figures as they were at 30 June 1989, namely, that 603 files had been opened by this Unit, and there were still 292 under investigation in some form or another, although those were being winnowed down to probably fewer than 50 cases that were likely to lead to prosecutions. However, it has now transpired that, despite that process and despite the fact that it looked as though this Unit was coming to a close, it was revealed to the Estimates Committee only last week that in fact 64 further files have been opened since 30 June 1989 and that, indeed, it expects to receive a further list of 55 persons from the Wiesenthal Centre. So another 119 files have been referred to this Unit despite the extensive investigation that it has been conducting for three years.

The cost of the Unit has now been revealed in this report. In the 2 3/4 years that it has been in operation to the period of this report it was $3.7m. It is estimated that the current year's operations will cost another $4m.

The most spectacular proceedings of the Unit's activities involve a prosecution which is going to run into constitutional problems. It is the subject of a High Court challenge which will be heard shortly. Perhaps of even more concern is the fact that there is a large committal proceeding to be heard and, as I understand it, evidence for this will be taken largely in the Soviet Union. Enormous expense will be incurred in the taking of all those depositions from witnesses in the Soviet Union. That is a point which I particularly express concern about because in our extensive debates in both chambers over the War Crimes Act the Attorney-General of the day, Mr Lionel Bowen, made it very clear that witnesses against any person accused of war crimes under this Act would be brought to Australia and available for the trials which would be taking place in Australia.

I hope that the fact that depositions are being taken in the Soviet Union, which depositions will be required for the committal proceedings, does not mean that ultimately this evidence-if it gets to trial-will be taken in written form and that the witnesses will not be brought to Australia. That would be a matter of very grave concern to many of us in both Houses of Parliament, particularly the Senate, which was assured that witnesses would be brought to Australia to answer before a trial in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak on the subject of the Special Investigations Unit's annual report. I think it is well known that I strongly opposed the War Crimes Act which this Special Investigations Unit (SIU) is the hatchet arm for-I suppose that is a way to describe them. I objected to the Act because, in my view, it was deeply divisive. It was in clear contrast to a resolution of the House of Representatives in 1961 which said, with all parties agreeing-there was only one dissenting voice-that the time had come to forget about the crimes of World War II and if migrants came to Australia and lived within our laws they need fear nothing in our courts about the events of the Second World War. This whole Act and the activities of the SIU are in clear defiance of that understanding reached by this Parliament nearly 30 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I will summarise briefly my objections to the Act because, of course, the SIU is implementing the Act. It is retrospective in the criminal sphere, which I think is very objectionable. A fair trial, as Senator Durack touched on, is almost impossible nearly 50 years after the event with witnesses being heard in places like the Soviet Union. There are enormous difficulties at this stage about the credibility of the witnesses. The legislation itself was very badly drafted. It confuses war crimes with crimes against humanity, which are quite different things; it is probably unconstitutional, because the international law on which it purports to rest did not exist at the time the offences were committed; and it is highly selective. It deals with only one small area of war crimes and crimes against humanity, those committed in Europe during the period from 1939 to 1945.

There have probably been 100 million crimes against humanity committed in the lifetime of living Australians. Why are we concentrating on such a small number? I am afraid I have always thought that the motive was entirely political, not legal, although I accept the very great distress caused to relatives of people who have been subject to or killed because of war crimes and crimes against humanity. Nevertheless we have the absurd situation where we are investigating, at enormous expense, crimes committed perhaps 50 years ago. Today if people committed a crime against humanity as defined by the Act in Cambodia, or in occupied Palestine for that matter, and subsequently emigrated to Australia the Special Investigations Unit would be unable to look at them. The Unit would be unable to do anything about them and they could not be charged with anything because the Act does not cover war crimes or crimes against humanity in general; it covers only particular ones in a particular area. That seems to me to be an outrage.

As Senator Durack said, the SIU spent $3.7m up to June 1989. It is now operating at a cost of about $4m a year and so far one person has been brought to trial. It is estimated that that trial and subsequent trials will cost $5 3/4m each. We have to think about why we are doing this. What social objectives are being achieved for Australia by this highly selective business of looking at events in another country 50 years ago?

I think this Unit will go on forever until all the conceivable people are dead because it still has 212 current files and is adding to them. Any time it is proposed to close the Unit down, the Unit will say, `Ah, we have a number of investigations very near completion, we must continue'. As it says in the SIU report, it is renewable each year in the Budget context. It will go on forever providing an enormous bonanza for the legal profession but no benefit, just deep division, for the Australian people. I hope the Government will close this Unit down as soon as possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the first week of this session of the new Senate I spoke for the Opposition when Senator Bolkus, on behalf of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), put down a statement that outlined a three-phase approach to his modifying the regulations under the Migration Act. The whole thrust of that ministerial statement, as I outlined then, was to respond to the serious failings of the draft regulations that had been promulgated by the Government on 19 December. To the extent that it was possible for the Minister to make specific changes to the regulations, as announced in that statement, it would be acknowledged by everybody that they are his Government's response to the two reports of the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted when I spoke for the Opposition, in responding to the Minister's statement, that whilst I could hold the two reports in my hand they had not been published and I could not refer to them. However, they have now been published. They are freely available and their full worth can be recognised by not only this chamber but all those in Australia who have a careful interest in immigration and ethnic affairs.

I should acknowledge that, with the cooperation of the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Joint Committee on a confidential basis brought our deliberations to the knowledge of some significant community groups with an interest directly in the Migration Act and the draft regulations. So whilst I commend the work of the Joint Committee whose reports we have now tabled, I wish to commend very truly those associations and individuals that made private submissions to us on a confidential basis because that was the limit of the consultation that was allowed to us in the agreement with the then Minister.

The most urgent aspect of the first report-to some extent this is a major item in the second-is the plea that the whole apparatus of law and regulations that was in draft to be promulgated on 19 December last was chiefly inadequate because it removed, for the first time, the kind of flexibility needed for a Minister to make sensible decisions in migration matters.

The then Minister, Senator Robert Ray, had been rather too preoccupied with stopping any possibility of corruption through even members of parliament, ethnic leaders or particular families that happened to have access to the Minister to put a case in private chambers for a matter to be approved. I welcome the intention of Senator Ray to stop such privileged access to a favourable government decision. As we know, there are about one million applications for immigration to this country every year and some 140,000, about 10 per cent, are successful.

In the past a great deal of emotional and other commitment was put to those marginal cases that might have been successful had an extra argument been put, had an extra basis been given for the Minister to approve the application. It is unfair if, say, only 10,000 out of that one million cases can be considered by the Minister. However, in remedying that kind of corruption of the system, the Minister was too determined and he removed from his own powers any ability to be compassionate. When I say any ability, I acknowledge that in an earlier stage in debating the Act we certainly provided for a review tribunal and any unsuccessful applicant could appeal to the tribunal for consideration, but the tribunal is bound by law exactly. If a case falls-despite the sense, justice or fairness of its being approved as one equivalent to others that are approved-the tribunal is powerless to find in favour of the applicant.

Because of the negotiations that the Opposition had with the Minister in the middle of last year, there is still a provision in the Act for the Minister to consider an unsuccessful applicant even after the tribunal stage and to approve it if it is in the national interest and if a persuasive case is presented, even if it is not strictly according to the guidelines that were binding the consideration of the application up to that point.

The burden of our first report was to say that this was still woefully inadequate. There needed to be an ability for the Minister to act in a much faster way, and so on. I note that the burden of the two reports has now been acted upon to a large extent in the ministerial statement that was put down a fortnight ago. I do not have the time, given the few minutes left to me here, to report upon a wide range of regulations, but now they are so publicly available they can be referred to by everybody and the good work of the Joint Committee can be seen for itself. I am delighted to see that there is going to be a continuing Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations and I wish that Committee very well.

In the two minutes that remain to me, I wish to touch upon a matter related to the whole burden of migration regulations. The Secretary to the Department, during the course of formulating the regulations-indeed, in setting up the procedures under the Act-determined in large degree the resources of the Department to achieve this quite radical reformulation of our immigration laws in this country. I refer to Mr Ron Brown. I refer to him here even though we will come to this matter in consideration of the Estimates Committee report tomorrow because I want to make it very clear that we still have not had in this chamber an explanation as to why the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) intervened and Mr Brown is no longer the head of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. We know that Mr Brown made a statement that he had chosen to retire from the Public Service and that he would be working as a private consultant, and we respect that decision. Mr Harris, the former Deputy Secretary, has also left the Department and is now working for the Industry Commission. We know factually that that is the case.

Whilst we have asked the question in this chamber of Senator Button and in the Estimates Committee hearing-we even received a written piece of paper following the Estimates Committee questions I put-we have not yet received actual answers to the question that the Opposition is putting about Mr Brown and Mr Harris. I want to alert the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), who is not responsible because these decisions were made before he was given the portfolio, that we intend tomorrow during consideration of the Estimates Committee report on the estimates of the Department of Immigration to have full and clear explanations of and exact answers to the questions that have been put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us today two reports from the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations. The first report was presented to the former Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs on 28 November 1989 and the second report was presented to the Minister on 12 December 1989. That is, these reports were presented to the Minister just some weeks before the final migration amendment legislation came before the Senate last year and also before the migration regulations were tabled on 19 December last year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has responded to these reports in three ways. Firstly, we saw the resignations which were referred to previously by you, Mr Acting Deputy President; that is, the resignations of two top level public servants from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Secondly, we had the Minister's statement concerning a projected review of migration regulations in which he stated that there would be considerable changes. Thirdly, in March this year there was a new edition of the Procedures Advice Manual, known as PAM. The changes to that manual cost some $102,000. We have seen, in the first few months of this year leading up to the election, a series of hasty changes brought in by the Government as a result of its bringing forward the legislation too quickly last year without proper research and information and also as a result of its producing a great number of regulations.

Those regulations are under severe criticism in both of the reports now before us. I commend the Government for acting upon the recommendations contained in the reports and changing the regulations to a considerable degree. However, the Government could quite easily have avoided that situation. It is tragic that this whole situation has degenerated into a charade. I use the word `tragic' because the whole immigration area affects people's lives so closely. People do not choose to migrate to another country just for fun or just on a sudden idea. It is often a matter which is debated in the family for some time. It is a matter which takes some organisation. If migrants who are looking to come to Australia are living in a country which has some form of internal problem, or where the family itself is in danger of being imprisoned by the authorities, they, of course, have other reasons for coming here. Nonetheless, the Government, when it chose to try to codify every single sort of circumstance that a migrant could come into or to categorise every single person who could seek to come to Australia, found that it simply could not do that. That is where this whole business went very wrong indeed.

I would like to refer briefly to the mandatory deportation orders. I asked at the Senate Estimates Committee hearing how many mandatory deportation orders had been issued by the Government since 19 December because this was a matter that had concerned me a great deal and also concerned some of the organisations which wrote into the Committee. In fact, the answer to that question was that there had not been one mandatory deportation order issued since 19 December.

The Department issued me with a list of the non-mandatory deportation orders which had been issued and the countries to which those people were deported, and I thank the Department for that. But I ask again: Why has the Government put in place a mandatory deportation order and a non-mandatory deportation order when, according to the list furnished to me, if a person is to be deported this is very easily done. The problems with the mandatory deportation orders are that, once they are signed and set in train, then, according to legislation, they cannot be stopped in any way, even if it is found that other information which was not previously available has become available.

The Government's response to that is to say, `Well, the person could simply be deported to Norfolk Island'. That person could then, presumably, be brought back into Australia, in which case it means that the mandatory deportation orders are themselves a farce and simply should not be there. So I take the opportunity again to make the plea to the Government to remove the mandatory deportation orders from the legislation because the government has already the power to deport people.

We learned that the harshness of the regulations is to be relieved in some way. And, indeed, I am sure that those of us here concerned with those migration regulations will look forward to seeing that promise of the Government brought into being. When, in December 1988, the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs announced that there would be a change in the migration laws and that they would be codified and made fairer, everybody in this chamber and, I am sure, everybody in the community at large was very pleased to hear it. But we had a very different sort of procedure before us. It seems now that the Government is willing to change its mind.

I am pleased that these reports have now been tabled and made public. I advocate that honourable senators read the criticisms contained in these reports. The Committee was very fortunate to have expert advice. It had the advice not only of various groups and organisations in the community to which it was able to send the draft regulations for comment, but also of an excellent consultant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Senator Coates:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Discussion of this report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is very timely as we are having an appropriations debate where in many instances we have found that annual reports, particularly from governmental authorities, have been very late indeed. In fact, we had an Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) report presented the day before yesterday the lateness of which seemed incredible. It was not as a result of any delay by the Auditor-General or any disputes on accounts, because the Auditor-General's report was signed in August of last year.
—it was just trying to keep it a secret, that is all.

—As Senator McKiernan says, it was just trying to keep it a secret. After all, it was ASIO. I do not want to flog a dead horse, but there is a real need for further improvement in reporting, particularly of non-statutory bodies and statutory bodies which do not have the same reporting requirements that the departments have. This report by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration indicates that departmental annual reports have been presented to the Senate in a far more timely way in the latest year than ever before. This massive improvement is, I believe, in large part due to the enthusiasm and energy of this Committee of the Senate, of which I might say I am not a member.

SPEECH.PARA: The statutory authorities, unlike the departments, are not legally bound by comprehensive and up-to-date reporting rules. The reporting rules for the departments of state require departmental heads to provide their Ministers by 31 December each year with a report on the operations of their departments during the year ended on the preceding 30 June. The same legislation requires that each annual report be tabled in both Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days of the report being received by a Minister.

A table in this report shows the nature of the significant improvement in the timeliness of departmental reports being presented to this chamber. In 1987-88 the number of departments of state that had reported by the end of November totalled only 10 out of 18. In the latest year that number of departments which had reported by the end of November increased to 17 out of 18. I commend the departments for their improvement and also for the fact that in most instances draft reports were made available to Senate Estimates committees so that those committees would be aware of matters of great significance raised in those annual reports.

To that extent I suppose it is unfortunate, as we are discussing these supplementary Estimates Committee hearings in the chamber this week, that some reports-for example, the Auditor-General's reports which are of great relevance to the matters we have been looking at-came in just after these matters were discussed. I urge the Auditor-General to ensure that his reports which bear relevance to the actions of the Senate's Estimates committees should be made available, if possible, before those meetings. After all, the Auditor-General should be able to be aware in advance of the dates of the Estimates committee hearings. It is a shame that the high level of work done by the Auditor-General is not being fully utilised at an appropriate time because of these slight delays in getting the reports before honourable senators. I make the point that while the departments have improved so strongly, the report states:

Statutory authorities, in contrast, report in accordance with guidelines that have not been updated since 1982 and that fall far short of the reporting requirements faced by government departments and major organisations in the private sector. The Committee recommended urgent review of the statutory authority guidelines in its 1989 report. Although there has been no substantive government response to the Committee's recommendations, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has begun an inquiry into the statutory authority reporting guidelines which is likely to resolve the problem.

The simple fact is that as this Government pushes more and more organisations into becoming statutory authorities, rather than authorities that report direct to Senate Estimates committees, there is a real risk of a diminished reporting responsibility of this chamber and an additional need for timeliness in reports by statutory authorities. I do not see why, if the body becomes a statutory authority rather than just a section of a department, it should not be under the same obligation to report speedily and thoroughly as departments are. I think the Government should be encouraged to proceed speedily to fix up a significantly growing problem.

I also mention that there has been an increase in the number of departments that have included audited accounts in their annual report. As I recall, only two last year failed to have an audited report in their annual report. I believe it is absolutely vital. Apart from anything else, it is important to see which departmental reports are qualified by the Auditor-General for failing to meet statutory requirements, or for any other matter. To that extent I am looking forward to the debate, perhaps later today, on some Auditor-General's reports which I hope will be presented to this chamber.
In conclusion, some of the non-statutory bodies under the control of some departments are not being appropriately referred to in departmental reports. That matter is raised in this report. It states:
Notwithstanding the considerable attention devoted to the subject-
that is, the matter of statutory and non-statutory bodies-
by this Committee and its predecessor, the presentation of information on non-statutory bodies (NSBs) in departmental reports remains far from satisfactory in many instances.
As there is no comprehensive listing of NSBs, it is not possible to verify that the coverage in the departmental annual reports is complete and accurate. Nevertheless, many defects were apparent.
Among the defects, for example, the report refers to the Treasury's annual report and states:
The introduction to the Treasury's report states that the Foreign Investment Review Board is the only non-statutory body within the portfolio.
In fact there are eight other non-statutory bodies known to exist within the Treasury portfolio and no reference whatsoever was made to them. I agree with the report, which concludes:
The coverage of the information on NSBs provided in the various departmental reports was variable and generally incomplete.

I believe that the Government should act on this area with speed. I support the Committee's report and endorse the fact that the Committee welcomes a significant improvement in the general quality of the majority of departmental annual reports. I only wish we could say the same about statutory bodies and non-statutory bodies. I also wish that we had greater access and greater capacity to deal with many of the limited liability corporations now being created by this Government which occupy an uncomfortable halfway house. We should have the capacity to examine them.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Development of the Senior Executive Service: Performance Based Pay

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Senator Coates:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this unanimous report put down by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled The Development of the Senior Executive Service: Performance Based Pay. From the outset I believe this exercise of trying to subvert the centralised wage fixing system is fraught with danger and is something that we should all be very well aware of.

SPEECH.PARA: The rationale behind performance based pay, theoretically, is linking the pay system to performance so as to provide an incentive for improved performance. As was put to us by many witnesses, in actual practice this does not seem to work. I refer to evidence given by one or two of those people, in particular Professor Robert Wood of the Graduate School of Management at the University of Western Australia who argued, firstly, that there were measurement problems associated with performance. He also said there were problems with the perceptions of equity.

Professor Wood also raised the question of privacy. In other words, when these particular performance payments are made, he queried whether they should remain private or whether they should become public. As a cynic I tend to believe that, even if that information were private, it certainly would not remain private for very long. That would have the effect of creating a certain amount of disenchantment with other members of the Senior Executive Service (SES) who did not receive performance pay. Another witness who is well known to quite a few honourable senators, John Nethercote, in his usual succinct manner stated:

[Performance based pay] misinterprets the motivations of our officials . . . They want reasonable remuneration but one reason we can have confidence in our senior officialdom is that monetary incentive is not uppermost in their minds . . . Most significantly, [Performance based pay] will be corrosive of a fundamental quality in public departments. To run successfully, they call for a high degree of collegiality and cooperation at senior levels.

It is interesting also to note some evidence given in a lecture by David Laughrin, a senior officer of the British Civil Service, who reported that the introduction of performance based pay in Great Britain encountered quite a number of problems. He said that it was-and I quote:

. . . much more difficult to deal with resistance and scepticism about the schemes than many of those responsible . . . expected. This was because they challenged the cultural values of the civil service. These values included an attachment to fairness, equity of treatment, openness on remuneration, and work relationships based on teamwork and group results . . . The result was that some of the early recipients, against all expert predictions, refused bonuses, paid them to charity, or shared them with their staff.

I think that that is most significant. Also, we heard evidence from Professor Rainer Koch of the University of the Federal Armed Forces of Germany, who indicated to us that the introduction of performance based pay in the West German Federal Civil Service in the early 1970s had been unsuccessful. The main reasons which he gave were that it was very difficult to define individual contributions to corporate performance. He was most scathing of any attempts that should be made by this Government to introduce this at such short notice.

As a result of those hearings, the Committee recommended that performance based pay not be introduced for the SES until a formal study of costs and benefits of the proposal has been undertaken and that it has been established that significant net benefits are likely. The evidence that came to light from the different departments was that, if this proposal goes ahead on 1 July, which we are led to believe will occur, a lot of departments do not have in place effective staff appraisal systems. It certainly seems a case of putting the cart before the horse.

It is fair to say that one of the biggest problems with performance based pay is that of having a fair and equitable appraisal system of the Senior Executive Service to allow the performance based pay to be paid in an equitable way. We were told in evidence, when we asked the Department of Finance how it intended to hand out this money-and it came as a shock to most of us, I believe-that it would hand a basketful of money, equivalent to a 10 per cent wage rise, to each department to dispose of as it wished. I was rather shocked that, if a department had a staff appraisal system in place, of those people judged to be capable of receiving an extra benefit or bonus, some would receive a bonus and others would not. So, in effect, the 10 per cent could become 20 or 30 per cent. I can understand that it could create a lot of staff morale problems.

We therefore recommend that, if performance pay is introduced, it not be introduced until an effective staff appraisal system had been operating for at least one year and had been independently evaluated. We also recommended that any performance pay be given as a bonus payment rather than as a supplement to regular salary payments. It is quite obvious to anyone who knows about the way the Public Service works that, on the one hand, if it is given as an annual supplement to regular salary payments, the whole intention of performance based pay would fall down. On the other hand, if it is given as a one-off bonus payment and if the performance of a particular officer is judged to be not as good as the year before, the bonus cannot be given. Therefore, we would end up with the staff member trying to increase his performance to receive a bonus in the next year.

The Committee had two major concerns. As I said earlier, one concern was that some departments do not have in place staff appraisal systems. The other concern related to the rush to implement this scheme in the next two months. If it is introduced, it certainly runs a great risk of failure. The whole matter was summed up very well by David Leaver when he said:

We still believe that it is being done . . . to get around the [wage] guidelines rather than because people have thought through the whole process. That is the wrong reason and that is a recipe for a stuff-up.
We hope that Mr Leaver was wrong, but the evidence we received-and we were unanimous in our report to the Senate-lends us to support that conclusion.

In conclusion, I just say that it is rather ironic that on 22 December, the Senior Executive Service of the Public Service, by broad banding its six wage grades into three, effectively increased its wage package on average between 6 and 19 per cent. When, or if, performance pay is implemented on 1 July, it will be awarded with the full support of the Government and the Industrial Relations Commission, at least another 10 per cent, and it could go as high as 30 per cent. So there is a total, potential increase in SES pay of anything between 16 and 40 per cent. Given the fact that Cabinet, in the last day or so, has given the okay for a 42 per cent increase to top public servants, it is ironic to remember the fight that was put up by the Government against the airline pilots who had an ambit claim of 29 per cent, and the destruction that that dispute caused our nation. Yet we see here, with the full approval of the Government, a performance based pay--
