DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON CERTAIN ASPECTS OF THE AIRLINE PILOTS DISPUTE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots dispute has presented its report. As a member of that Committee, I wish to address one element in the report relating to the cost charged by the Commonwealth for the use of Royal Australian Air Force aircraft by the airlines throughout the dispute. When the Committee was sitting, we simply did not have any information as to how those costs were put together. It is only today, in response to a question I asked at an Estimates committee, that that information has become available to us from the Department of Defence. I wish to comment on that very briefly. The overriding characteristic of the charges levied by the Commonwealth for the use of Boeing 707, Hercules and Hawker Siddeley 748 aircraft, is that it was such an unbelievably low charge.
—How much was the 707?

—I will come to that. The airlines were charged only in the order of $2,970 per flying hour. As someone who has owned and operated aircraft in a private capacity for over 20 years, I find the costing absolutely unbelievable. It was a gift-a straight-out subsidy to the airlines by the Government. What has become clear in the response from the Department of Defence today is that the Department was ordered to recover only the additional cost level. That was never made clear to the Committee. But in the report from the Defence Department today the additional cost level is defined as the cost which neglects the servicing charges by the Air Force and the manpower needed to maintain the aircraft. There is no inclusion of the capital depreciation and none of the overheads for owning the aircraft are included. In other words, it is a direct operating cost of the aircraft with not even an aircrew component in it. The additional costs are defined in the Defence Department report as having three basic components-fuel, spare parts and contractor servicing. We would remember that the fuel component was agreed to be picked up by the airline. In the end, there was some mess-up about that. The Air Force ended up providing some of its own fuel.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extraordinary basis on which to charge for the hire of the aircraft. Originally, the Air Force came to the airlines and said, `We estimate it will cost us $12,031 an hour for a Boeing 707 and $4,953 an hour for a C-130 aircraft'. In the end, the airlines paid not $12,031 an hour for a Boeing 707 but $2,970; they paid not $4,953 an hour for the Hercules but $806.

The mickey mouse economics that the Defence Department, at the Government's behest, was forced to implement were based on this mythology of an additional cost. The more hours that were flown the more the additional cost was diluted. The additional cost was taken as being developed by this spares holding, which was on a five-year average, and the contractor servicing for fixed charges, and divided by the number of hours flown. So the more hours flown, the more the cost came down.

It is an entirely dishonest way to calculate cost. It is true that there are fixed costs such as insurance and the holding of fixed spares, as well as the mandatory inspections that have to be done on a calendar basis as opposed to an hours flown basis. The other side of the operating costs of an aircraft relates very much to the hours flown. They do not get cheaper the more hours one flies. A classical example of that is engine costs. The life of an engine is calculated by the number of hours it runs, not by the number of hours since it was last overhauled and sits in a hangar. I do not know what it costs to overhaul the engines in a Boeing 707. I do not even know what particular Pratt and Whitney engines they are. But, by way of comparison, I know that years ago the PD6 turbine engines in a Twin Otter cost about a quarter of a million dollars each to overhaul. I presume that the much larger engines in the Boeing 707 could quite realistically cost at least $1m each to overhaul-maybe $1.5m; I do not know. With four of those engines, one would be looking at a running cost of at least $800, maybe $1,000, an hour in engine costs alone to operate that aircraft. None of this was factored into the charges that a generous government levied against the airlines for the use of those aircraft.

The report from the Department of Defence establishes, without the slightest shadow of doubt, that the Government embarked on a massive subsidy to its good mates, Sir Peter Abeles of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Mr Harris of Australian Airlines Ltd. It was nothing more than a blatant transfer of funds from the taxpayer to two companies. That is absolutely wrong. The Department of Defence has had its funds cut back pretty well every year by this Government. It is very short of funds. It has massive resignation rates, high training costs, cutbacks in operational training exercises and all the rest of it. At the end of the day, the Department of Defence will have to pick up a very large part of the cost of this, for which it will receive no recompense at all from the Government.

A great difficulty we had with this report was working out the Government's motives. We simply did not know why Mr Hawke was being so generous to Mr Abeles and Australian Airlines. Why did the Government not do something to resolve the pilots strike? The evidence given to the Committee was that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots was prepared to settle that dispute from 12 September. But there was a lockout by the airlines, which was actively supported by the Government, against any resolution of the strike.

The cost of that strike is absolutely devastating. Hundreds of tourist industry businesses in Queensland have gone out of business because they have gone bankrupt. We have lost billions of dollars. Our international reputation as a tourist destination has been destroyed for years and it will not be re-established quickly.

We have seen a core of about 16,070 pilots reduced to about half that number. The cream of that pilot core-the professional body of airmen in Australia-has gone to airlines such as Malaysia Airlines, Singapore Airlines Ltd and, particularly, Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. Pretty well all the check and training captains from Australian Airlines went. We are left with the pilots that could not get jobs with overseas airlines. The overseas airlines picked the eyes out of them. Where would we be today if the cream of our surgeons went to work in America, the United Kingdom or another country?

In addition to those who went overseas, a large number of pilots who were close to retiring age said, `We do not want any part of this' and took premature retirement. The loss of expertise can be seen in the way the aircraft are being operated today. This dispute should never have occurred. Opposition members on that Committee do not support the action of the pilots. We speak out against it. But the greatest folly of all was the folly of the Government in actively supporting the airline management, which, for reasons of very short-sighted commercial advantage, chose to take on the pilots federation with no thought at all for the consequences to this nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, Chairman of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, I present the Committee's first report of 1990. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 2 of 1990, dated 23 May 1990.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 May on motion by Senator Devereux:
That the following Address-in-Reply be agreed to:
To His Excellency the Governor-General
MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY-

We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign and to thank Your Excellency for the speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Campbell, I remind honourable senators that this is the honourable senator's first speech. Therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him. I call Senator Campbell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. It is a great honour to be selected by the Liberal Party of Western Australia and appointed by the Parliament of Western Australia to represent my great State here in the Senate. At the outset, I pay tribute to my colleague and predecessor, Fred Chaney. Fred Chaney's career in the Senate was long and distinguished and I wish him great success during his time in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel a strong sense of responsibility to the people of Western Australia, representating them as I now do as a senator. There are few times in the past two decades when a new member, rising to make his maiden speech, could not have been confronted with a feeling of urgency and the need to reform. I guess it becomes somewhat repetitive and trite to restate the necessity for political action to solve this nation's significant problems, when this has been so often and so clearly stated before. Yet, no matter how often this has been stated by past generations, the myriad of problems facing our nation remains. Many of the problems have worsened considerably despite the very best efforts of very well intentioned politicians who have been elected to this Parliament in the past two decades. There is certainly an intertia which permeates the political process and seems to frustrate the course of reform and adjustment.

What then are the causes and where are the solutions? For a long time I have believed that it is important that one's community activity should involve an interest in politics. This belief is clearly not shared by many of my generation. There is a deep-seated mistrust of politicians and a lack of understanding of politics. Those of us who have pursued the pilgrimage to parliament and who sit in the various parliaments share many common ideals and make significant sacrifices in the pursuit of those ideals. In the main, we are committed to the institution of parliamentary democracy. We also have our own visions for a better future for our nation and the well-being of our fellow Australians. Those visions vary as do our philosophies and the policies we would pursue to achieve those visions.

As a Young Liberal State President in the early 1980s, I toured around secondary schools in Western Australia with the non-partisan objective of encouraging the youth of Western Australia to become involved in political parties. Indeed, I encouraged those young Western Australians to join the political party of their choosing and to take a role in determining the future shape of this nation. I implored them, as a young Winston Churchill had done so many decades before, to consider the question, `Does our nation always have to be ruled by old men?'. I ask, `Why cannot many young men and women concerned for the future of their nation, for their generation and for future generations, become active in the politics of their nation?'. Government does not always have to be in the hands of the older generation.

It is heartening to see that over the past few years the coalition parties across this nation have actively encouraged younger members to gain high office, both in the organisational wings and the parliamentary wings. I feel sure that this augers well for the rebirth of our fortunes. But the fact does remain that membership of political parties in Australia is very low-shamefully low. I am sure that if all political parties achieve an increase in membership at a grassroots level, our political parties will become more vibrant and representative and the political process will win.

In recent weeks we have heard much spoken about community disdain for politicians on both sides of the political fence. The quality of our politicians and our accountability reflects the level of community involvement in the political process. The people of Australia get the government they deserve. I put it to the Senate that we do deserve better.

It is vital that the politics of the 1990s are very different from the politics of the 1980s. Politics in the 1980s were domi- nated by the tactics described in the book Programming the President-I guess, in Australian terms, it would be called `Programming the Prime Minister'. During the past decade of missed opportunities, our game was led by telephone polling and opinion polling. Policy was dictated by the politics of expediency with the longest term vision being firmly focused on the next Morgan gallop poll.

I do not direct all of my criticism at the current Government. Former State and Federal governments squandered vital opportunities to implement long needed and important reforms. The examples of good words and noble rhetoric not being matched by good deeds and real action would fill a tome and are part of the cause of why politicians are not trusted.

One example that is very close to my heart and has been high on the agenda of the Liberal Party of my generation is voluntary student unionism. The principle of freedom of association and the individual's right to choose to join or not join a union is a fundamental philosophy in which I believe. It is a principle that has been supported by the Liberal Party across Australia for many years. Yet, Liberal State governments in the early 1980s right across Australia failed to apply this philosophy when it came to student unionism and the payment of student union fees. I eagerly await the next era of Liberal-State governments and trust that they will use their power to implement this long overdue reform. Again, I look forward to the New South Wales Liberal Government showing the leadership that is required in this policy area. Men and women must be free to choose whether or not to join a union. There are no special cases and there are no exceptions. We must be free to choose.

Clearly, this philosophy must also apply to industrial trade unions. I suggest that the continuing decline in union membership across Australia cannot be arrested by the formation of 20 mega-unions. The percentage of people in the work force who are members of trade unions has fallen from 51 per cent in 1976 to 42 per cent in 1988-the last figure recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. As with any organisation, when a union becomes too large the distance between the grassroots and the leadership becomes too great and the hopes and aspirations of the rank and file become very remote from the agenda pursued by the union bosses.

I believe that trade unionism can be a positive force for Australia, but it needs to be democratic. The membership needs to be voluntary and the trade union leadership must reflect the needs of its membership. These needs will clearly vary from enterprise to enterprise, from State to State and from region to region. But I suggest again that the future of unionism is in decentralising it-taking control back closer to the grassroots. If we can do this, the proportion of those who are members of unions will actually rise. I am convinced that the current approach to union amalgamation and centralisation will hasten the current decline. Big government, big unions, big business and their cosy deals have ruined this big country. I hope that the era of the big deal is over.

There are three policy areas that I wish to concentrate on in this speech, namely, micro-economic reform, federalism in the 1990s and environmentally sustainable economic development. There is no doubt that there is a growing consensus about the dire economic circumstances in which we find ourselves today. In the early 1980s we referred to the `misery index', which was derived from adding the inflation rate to the prevailing unemployment rate. We could now claim to be beating almost every other nation in the civilised world in terms of an index of doom. I proposed that a cocktail derived from adding the net foreign debt as a proportion of gross domestic product of 32.9 per cent to the inflation rate of 8.6 per cent, an unemployment rate of 6.2 per cent and prime lending rates of 18.5 per cent would create a staggering index of 86.2 per cent. Of course, this is a very meaningless figure statistically, but it is a stark reminder of the sort of pain that people, their families and their businesses are undergoing. It shows why our economic activity has stalled.

We need to work hard to bring about a downward trend in this doom index, and perhaps on this day every year we could look at that figure again and see whether we are succeeding in this place to do just that. Of course, the bringing down of this index can be achieved only by providing an economic environment where the hopes and aspirations of individuals can be realised.

The vast majority of Australians do believe in the concept of reward for effort, a fair day's work for a fair day's pay, and an extra reward for an extra hard day's work. Australians are competitive by nature and will always rise to meet a challenge. We have proven that time and again on the sporting field where we have taken on the best the world can offer, and won. But the prerequisite to this success is a level playing field, clearly defined goals and incentives to achieve those goals.

This environment does not exist in Australia at the moment, and that is why the political agenda of the 1990s has the words `Micro-economic reform' written in big letters at the top. Australia cannot compete successfully on the world market with the inherent structural rigidities and inefficiencies which afflict our productivity as a nation. The Liberal Party, for the past seven years, has championed the policies of deregulation and privatisation. These are the fundamentals of micro- economic reform.

There is now a high level of debate within the Government about the pace of this reform, but the Government is severely handicapped by the political forces within Caucus, pressure from its trade union constituency, and outdated ideological baggage which maintains a com- mitment to centralised control and government ownership of trading enterprises. I hope that the Liberal Party in Opposition can contribute to this debate. Our policies prescribe urgent and rapid reform, and we will, by leading the debate, blaze a trail that will, to some extent, assist the Government.

There is little use in talking in the language of micro-economic reform, privatisation and deregulation as most people in the community do not really understand what these terms mean. But people do understand the concept of freedom and of free enterprises. People are generally aware of waste and inefficiency and the lack of responsiveness to change within govemment. We are all exposed to it every day. People are also aware of the strong dedication to service and the needs of the customer within privately owned busi- nesses, and few would argue that if we can transfer the operations out of the Government sector and into the private sector then our economy will become more vibrant. Of course, the great thing about this transfer into the private sector is that it need not be revolutionary; it can also be done without causing dislocation.

However, what it will do is increase opportunities for Australians and create far more flexibility and choices in employment. At the moment, 27.2 per cent of our working population is employed within the government sector. I suggest that, as the number of people employed in the free enterprise sector and within small business increases, there will be greater freedom, as people employed within the private sector will have more flexibility in career moves.

I have always said to those people who have worked with me that when the morning comes that they do not want to leap out of bed and tear into work, that is the morning that they should start looking for a new job, because no-one should have to spend five or six days out of a seven day week doing something that does not provide them with both personal satisfaction and adequate financial rewards. This is what privatisation and micro-economic reform is really about. It is about creating a better environment for each and every Australian to achieve their full potential.

This should be the focus of the debate and the test of any micro-economic reform agenda. What does micro-economic reform achieve for individual Australians in terms of creating more opportunities and more economic freedom? It should not relate to the needs of peak employer groups, peak trade unions and government, for when these groups set the agenda the individual loses out. One of my goals as a senator is to see privatisation and deregulation policies communicated in digestible language and to see these policies successfully implemented. When we talk of privatisation it is no longer a question of will we do it, but a matter of when-and I will use all my energies to ensure that that is so.

One of my other fundamental objectives as a senator representing Western Australia is to maintain a strong and vibrant federal system. Too often in the past the rhetoric of federalism has concentrated on States rights. This is seen to be reactionary, conservative and parochial. Centralists who usually, and not coincidentally, live in the more populous States often use the phrase `States rights' to demean the politics of federalism. As a phrase, States rights shares the weakness of privatisation, in that it is not very descriptive and can readily be misused. Indeed, the advocates of States rights who use the phrase and then leave it to stand alone as if it is self-evidently righteous do more harm than good in the debate on the inherent benefits of the federal system. The benefit of a decentralised political system is that decision making is kept close to the people.

Government and Parliament are accessible and responsible to individual and community needs. Yet since Federation we have witnessed an entire procession of politicians from all political parties come into this place and try to centralise power. The proponents of centralisation would have us believe that it is more efficient to centralise control into one government and that we can get rid of duplication and make things more efficient by doing just that. The same logic could be applied to a dictatorship or a one party state: it is very efficient but far from my vision of representative and accountable democracy.

The most successful companies in the private sector ensure that decision making and responsibility are delegated right down the line to ensure that the customer deals with the decision maker. The world wide trend to franchising is evidence of this. At a time when businesses, faced with fierce and escalating international competition, are decentralising to ensure they can adapt to change quickly, we are continuing to centralise political power. At a time when the nations of the Eastern bloc are clambering for democratically self elected government, we are continuing to centralise power in the Federal Government at the expense of the States.

My proposition is that Australia cannot become more competitive and more adaptive to a rapidly changing international economic climate without a decentralised political system. Our commitment to federalism must be based on this principle and not on reactionary States rights dogma.

Federalism does not mean buying off the States with grants and handouts and large regional offices. It requires real control by the States of those areas of responsibility not reserved for the Commonwealth under the Constitution. The current negotiations over the control of corporations and securities law are a classic example of the States being bought out by the Commonwealth. I implore the business community to see this centralist grab for power for what it is. The business community must send a clear message to the State governments that are caving in to the Commonwealth's national scheme. Business people across Australia must inform the State governments that control and accountability for corporate affairs has to be retained at the State level where the majority of business activity takes place. This does not deny the need for a strong national corporate watchdog, which must be well resourced. But this can all be achieved by an upgraded and more accountable cooperative scheme.

No matter what the Federal Government promises today about the level of services that businesses in the outlying States will receive from the Australian Securities Commission, that promise will be irrelevant, because control and resources will be determined here and will not be responsible to business communi- ties at the local level.

The development of federalism during the 1990s must proactively decentralise both power and responsibility and reduce Federal Government intervention and control. I am dedicated to achieving this shift away from centralised power for the benefit of both my nation and the people of Western Australia.

I am also committed to achieving environmentally sustainable economic growth. Again, many centralists would have us believe that the only way to achieve economic growth and protect the environment at the same time is to hand over control to Canberra. Of course, much of this control has already been assumed by the abuse of the external affairs power and the use of World Heritage listings.

When we move down the path of centralised government control through regulation and prohibition then a whole diversity of environmental enterprise and entrepreneurship will be smothered at birth. The recent Globe 90 international conference in Canada focused world attention on the potential for environmental management and associated technology to become a rapidly growing industry in this decade. It is an industry in which Australia is very well placed to lead the world, and I put it to the Senate that it is a potential source of future export income. But this can occur only if the Government stays right out of it.

The growing environmental consciousness is a worldwide movement of public opinion. It is a grassroots change that will reshape our industries and technologies, but this will be from the ground up. It is the sort of change that is naturally suited to a decentralised decision making and law making structure. Dr David Suzuki's catchcry of `Think globally and act locally' is to me a call to our fellow man to do away with the rhetoric and take action. That action starts in our very own backyards. It embraces local communities, our towns, our cities, our regions, our States, and a shared responsibility for our nation and our world. This should be the order of priority for our environment policies. We must reject calls to hand over control of the environment to the government in Canberra. We must encourage local action on local problems and cooperative solutions to national and global problems.

The environment debate during the 1990s should not be fought on the grounds of how `green' one politician or one political party claims to be. This is quite irrelevant and quite transparent. I know many environmentalists around this country who would have been sickened to see politi- cians jumping on the Green band wagon and saying, `Me too'. The debate must focus on how best to create the framework which will harness the force of individual commitment and enterprise in achieving our vision of a healthy economy and a protected environment. I think I have made it pretty clear that there are two paths down which we can travel: one is the path of centralised control and regulation and the other is that of encouraging free market solutions which provide incentives for individuals, businesses and industries to enhance and protect our environment.

There has been a rapidly increasing level of information about our environment. This has created a healthy awareness of the long term damage that can be caused by disregard for natural ecosystems. This awareness exerts both political and market pressures on governments and industry. Industry is forced to take a longer term view than just looking towards the next quarter's profits. Companies which pollute the environment will be put out of business by the consumers of their end products. This market pressure was evi- denced by research referred to in the Australian Financial Review of 16 May. The Quaker Oats company in Canada found that 41 per cent of Canadians had either stopped buying or switched brands on the basis of company environmental records. This is a trend in consumer behaviour which, no doubt, will become even more widespread as the years go by. This behaviour is far more effective at regulating the actions of industry than arbitrary limits imposed through regulation and bureaucracy.

I am not advocating `She'll be right' and that we can just leave it all to the private sector, because there is a very important role required of political leadership. We do have a responsibility to ensure that resources such as clean water, clean air and forests are protected for the benefit of mankind in perpetuity. Past generations of Australians have been responsible for visiting some major environmental disasters upon this nation, but I do not think it is fair, relevant or helpful for us to place all the blame on our forefathers. What is relevant is that our generation assume responsibility for rectifying those past mistakes. What we must also do is ensure that our natural environment-and our knowledge of how to manage it-is passed on to the future generations in a far better condition. This is a goal I will work towards as a senator and a goal I will encourage my generation to share.

I look forward to redefining the debate and the objectives of micro-economic reform, the relevance of federalism in this new age, and environmentally sustainable economic development. My Party clearly has not been successful in communicating its philosophies and principles in these areas in the past, but I do look forward to dedicating my efforts to communicating these policies while in opposition and making sure they are implemented when next we return to government.
In conclusion, I consider it a great honour and privilege to serve alongside my colleagues in the Senate and to work for the achievement of these goals. I thank the Senate.
Opposition members-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave of the Senate to continue the speech I was making in the Address-in-Reply which was interrupted to allow a maiden speech some days ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. It is an important speech for the people I am referring to, and it would look a little bald left as it was, without being completed. I am grateful for the opportunity to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Without going over all the matters I had referred to, I was speaking about those people who I believe have been neglected by the Government. I refer to those who are dependent for their incomes to an extent on the activities of the Child Support Agency and who receive maintenance for children through that Agency. I have complained previously in this place, and did on the last occasion I spoke, about the fact that the Agency is not operating properly. I support the work of the Agency, but I believe it must be made to work effectively and efficiently and to see the the money that is paid to it gets to those who need it.

I think I told the Senate that I had been invited by the Melbourne office of the Agency to visit and see what it was doing. I have no complaint about the Melbourne office of the Agency. I have had no dealings with that office and I certainly do not go to Melbourne very frequently. I am talking about the difficulties people in Canberra and the surrounding districts have in getting their money out of the Child Support Agency. I am talking about the many instances where advice duly supplied as to the whereabouts of a non-custodial father was not acted upon or was acted upon so late that the information was already out of date and opportunities for recovering maintenance were thereby lost. I am not talking about delays of just a few weeks; I am talking about delays of several months. I am talking about excessive delays in acting on variations of court orders, occasioning loss of maintenance. I am talking about the total failure to act to recover arrears of maintenance owed, failure to issue summonses and failure to commence recovery action.

I am talking about numerous instances of lost or mislaid forms, causing delays in starting maintenance recovery. I am talking about failure to pay money to clients on the basis that they had been overpaid, with no explanation offered as to how the Agency worked out that there had been an overpayment. Where moneys have been paid by a person to the Agency for the support of children they ought to be passed on, not held by the Agency because it believes there has been an overpayment. I am talking about the Agency's refusal to pass on maintenance duly and voluntarily paid for a child the subject of a court order. I am talking about the failure to process payments received on time so that they can be paid on time.

It is little wonder that the Agency's phones are running hot with inquiries from its clients wondering about the status of their cases and what is being done for them. When I refer to the phones of the Agency running hot I mean phones, because there is no office in Canberra that a person can go to to sort out the problems I am speaking of. It is much more difficult to do that over the phone-assuming, of course, that the phone is answered when a call is made to the Agency's office in Sydney. Unfortunately, the experience of many women who have contacted me is that they feel they are met by an unsympathetic and unhelpful response when they do get an answer to their calls. One woman who rang me had rung the Agency to inquire why the consumer price index increase had not been added, as stipulated in the court order-an adjustment upwards, annually, as is the case with many, in accordance with the CPI. She was told that she would have to calculate this herself.

It was lucky for this woman that she knew how to go about getting the official quarterly CPI statistics from the Bureau of Statistics. It was lucky that she was in Canberra and it was able to be done relatively easily. She had to do the calculation herself and provide the information to the Agency as to the amount that should then be paid by way of an increase in maintenance before it would even contemplate writing to the father to ask him to increase the amount that he was paying. As I said, it was fortunate that this woman was able to do these calculations. Many in the community would not have known where to get the CPI figures from, would not have the numeracy level and efficiency with numbers to work out the sum to be paid, or to even feel confident that they had done so.

Another woman who was owed several hundred dollars in arrears and who inquired what the Agency was doing to recover the money was informed that there were people in more need than she; that she was a low priority. How the officer speaking to her was qualified to judge this I really do not know. It is worth noting that this response from the Agency implied that it was pursuing larger debts. I do not know how large they need to be before they are regarded as being sufficiently large to warrant action by the Agency. But I am in contact with one woman owed several thousand dollars in maintenance who has had no more success than the woman owed a few hundred dollars. It seems astonishing to me that anyone could regard maintenance being paid through the Child Support Agency as not of sufficient importance to give collection of it a very high priority.

Another woman rang the Agency to ask why her money had not turned up. The money had been received by the Agency on the last day for the cut-off but the Agency had failed to key the amount into the computer and the payment could not be made. She was told that she could go to Social Security to get an advance on her pension. She told the Child Support Agency Officer that she was not on a pension and was then quizzed by the officer as to why she was not out working. He clearly had concluded that she really did not need the money. I repeat: How could people be dealing with the Child Support Agency if they did not need the money for the support of the children in their care? This woman was told that she was just one of 48,000 cases in New South Wales and that a special case could not be made out for her.

I have had numerous complaints with regard to the Agency, for example, phone calls not being returned; letters not being answered; long waits on the telephone to get through; officers who will not give their names to clients so that they cannot ring and get to the same person a second time; and, if one gets a name, one can never get the same person on the phone again when one rings back. The other excuse which is used quite frequently is that the computers are down. One might frivolously ask-down where? As far as the clients are concerned they might just as well be.

It seems to me, from the dealings that my office has had with the Agency, that there is a real morale problem. I feel very sorry for the staff who are trying to work there. Clearly, they are not sufficient in number to do the job efficiently and well. Therefore, there is a very high staff turnover. People obviously feel very unhappy that they are not able to do the job properly. The area is understaffed. As a result, the staff are harassed and overworked. Clearly, the new staff are not receiving adequate training before they are thrown into the job. As a result, the clients become frustrated with and justifiably angry at the treatment that they receive from the Agency. That is why so many people have come to my office to seek intervention on their behalf. All they want to know, mostly, is what is happening and that is what they cannot find out.

My office has had considerable dealings with the Agency looking after Canberra clients, the Chatswood office. We have experienced many of the same problems in getting information that clients of the Agency who have come to me as constituents have had, for example, failure to return phone calls and officers being unwilling to supply a name so that a follow-up can be pursued with the same person. There have been occasions when we felt that the `intrusion', one might call it-that is the way it seems to be-of my office was not welcomed at all. There does not seem to be a recognition of the fact that something within the Agency is causing this amount of unhappiness, and the intervention of a third party, that is, a member of parliament was not welcomed.

I want to refer to some of the most recent encounters. In making inquiries on behalf of four women having problems with the Agency we were trying to find what was happening with each of their respective cases. In three of the cases maintenance was in arrears and, supposedly, action was being taken in the enforcement section. In two of the cases it was the slowness of the Agency itself which had contributed to the accumulation of arrears. There were two situations where the client had duly provided all the information necessary for the Agency to commence recovery by way of direct deduction from the salary of the payer, but in both instances it had not occurred.

One woman had sent in her application with all the details in January 1989 but it was not until May that the Agency contacted the ex-husband's employer to request the withholdings. The employer promptly complied and sent his paperwork back so that the deductions could start from June. From January to May of 1989 nothing was recovered, and this woman is supposed to be supporting her children with that money.

When asked why this was the case, my office was told that it could have been incompetence, lack of training or carelessness but that there was little point in raking over it. I do not agree with that. When asked what was being done to recover the arrears for this period, the advice given was that it was in the hands of the enforcement section. The officer to whom my office was speaking could not tell from the computer records how this was progressing. A similar situation existed with the other two cases to which I have referred.

There are occasions, of course, when one gets on to somebody at the Agency who is most anxious to be helpful but who is not able to do what he would like to do. The girl in this particular case was not able to get us through to the enforcement section. When she tried to find out the phone number of the enforcement section for us so that we could ring it directly, she was told that numbers for the enforcement section would not be made available. It is an extraordinary situation.

I repeat that I believe it is because the Government has not provided sufficient staff for the job that the Agency is trying to do that the staff are getting frustrated and leaving. New ones are coming on and are not being adequately trained to proceed in the way that they would like to.

There is a question of accountability-accountability to the clients who are dealing with the Agency. Many people have sought to deal with the Agency because they believed that that would be the best way to proceed with the collection of maintenance, so that there would be a record for both parties and that everything would proceed smoothly. As a consequence many have been disillusioned. They feel utterly powerless to do anything about dealing with the Agency because of its situation in Sydney and because there is no office in Canberra. There are others they have to ring. I am not suggesting for a minute that we should have an Agency office in every town, but when we think of the number of people in Canberra and its districts, it does seem surprising that it cannot be handled better than it is at present.
The Agency is not able adequately to provide the service its clients deserve and which it was intended it should carry out. However, I will not go over the details that I have already referred to.

I repeat that there is evidence of a very high staff turnover. I believe that it is not the will of those within the Agency that things are turning out as they are. We must remember also that since it was set up in 1988 it has had additional responsibilities added to its original charter; that is, the imposition of the administrative formula which now operates to determine the amount of maintenance that any given person is required to pay. I will not go into the details of the formula. I am not challenging that. I am merely indicating that there is now a great deal more work to be done by the Agency to get the information that is required to assess the amount of money that ought to be paid by a person for children when the matter is being dealt with by the Agency. I think that considerably more staff and more training are required to enable staff to do the job that we expect of them.

I hope that the Government will take this problem seriously. It is not just a few Canberra women who have come to me that I am talking about; it is everybody who is dealing with the Agency and who is entitled to expect that it will provide for their children in the way in which it was intended when the legislation went through this Parliament. The Government has made a lot of commitments to women and children and to children in poverty, and the legislation which set up the Agency is a prime example of its achievements. I challenge the Government to make it work and make it work in a way that is meaningful for those who rely on it. It is false economy to skip on the necessities of the system and the structures that are necessary to make it work.

As a consequence, staff who ought to be dealing with payments coming in and going out are spending much of their time dealing with inquiries-the sort of inquiries, just a few of which I have mentioned-which I have received through my own office. If staff are tied up endlessly on inquiries we are not achieving what we set out to do. The mere fact that there are so many inquiries to the Agency ought to be an indication to the Government and to the Minister that something needs to be done.

The Government's own admission is that the Agency has not been as successful as anticipated in collecting and recovering maintenance. An independent report released in January showed that it was originally expected that savings to the taxpayer would amount to $120m in 1988-89 and $190m in 1989-90. This would have been derived from reductions in social security payments to sole parents who would now be getting maintenance. It is clear that these estimates were substantially over-optimistic. When the report was released the expected savings for 1988-89 were estimated at a mere $20m, not the $120m originally foreshadowed. Savings for 1989-90 are estimated to be in the region of only $40m.

The report itself lays some blame at delays in starting the scheme and getting it functioning as it should. No-one doubted that there would be teething problems. The report noted the delays in getting payments to custodial parents after an order had been registered with them. The then Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, reportedly expressed his concern about it. He is alleged to have said that it is important to recognise that this delay occurs only once before the first payment is made. It is unfortunate, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I have to tell you that that is not the case.

There is much to be done in this area. As I said, I have spoken on it before. I hope not to have to speak on it again. I believe that it is in the Government's interests to put a bit more effort into making sure that the Agency functions properly. I certainly hope that it will do this for the sake of the clients who rely on it. There is enough stress being a sole parent with an inadequate income without the worry of maintenance not coming through, especially when we know that it has been paid.

I appeal to the Government to look at the matter for the sake of the staff who are attempting to work within the Agency, and to thereby increase the savings on the social welfare expenditure and convince women who are presently getting less than adequate treatment that there is some basis for the Government's alleged claim to be concerned about women and children living in low income families.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this very lengthy Auditor-General's report, report No. 32, which we have received today and which is of some substance. This report reveals that both on the revenue and the payments side there are some improvements that need to be made to protect taxpayers' interests and the interests of all Australians. It also reveals some fiddles being done by departments playing around with their balances at the end of the year to make certain that they are theoretically spent to ensure that the money does not get taken from them out of the following year's allocations. This 30 June fiddle is well-known, and the Auditor-General is on to it and has revealed it in some instances which I will deal with briefly later.

SPEECH.PARA: The key elements of this report concern the financial statement relating to the aggregate financial statements of the Government, and it says:
revenue collections in the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Customs Service were adversely affected by the incidence of evasion and other breaches of relevant legislation
overpayments of benefits may have occurred at the Department of Social Security and Employment, Education and Training where payments were partially dependent on voluntary compliance, and

some pharmaceutical benefits were paid to pharmacists by the Department of Community Services and Health when entitlement was not evident and where prescriptions were incorrectly categorised because of insufficient verification of claims.
The Auditor-General notes some problems with controls over expenditure. In the report he says:

The Secretaries of the Departments of Social Security, Aboriginal Affairs and Employment, Education and Training were unable to certify, in their respective certificates on the financial statements, that payments of benefits and allowances under various programs of Commonwealth assistance were made in all instances in accordance with the program legislation and or established entitlement criteria.
I do not want to go into great depth about the extent to which those breaches took place. There is a list of breaches at the end of this report.
In relation to the matter of pharmaceutical benefits the Auditor-General said:

The audit reports on the financial statements prepared by the Department of Community Services and Health and the Department of Veterans' Affairs made reference to varying degrees of incorrect payments made under the Pharmaceutical Benefits and Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits schemes respectively. Payments under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme are made under the National Health Act 1953 and amounted to in excess of $1 billion in the 1988-89 financial year. Payments under the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme are made under the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 and amounted to approximately $90m . . .

Both departments have advised ANAO that because of the high volume and low individual value of claims processed it was neither practical nor cost effective to make full validation cheques prior to payment.
Nonetheless, the Audit Office concluded:
. . . that the checks carried out by the departments had not been sufficient to reduce incorrect payments to a satisfactory level.
That is a clear statement from the Auditor-General that incorrect payments are at an unsatisfactory level in this area. The report goes on to say:

The existence of a high error rate in the validity of entitlement numbers and the limited nature of post payment checking undertaken by the Department of Community Services and Health was . . . raised . . .
It was raised earlier last year. There was a response to this from the Department. The Audit Office now says:
. . . however, considered that the limited post payment checks in place were not sufficient to ensure that significant misuse of the system was prevented.
With respect to the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Audit Office considered:

. . . that there was not evidence that the Department had undertaken a formal risk assessment regarding the nature and level of post payment checks which ANAO considered desirable in view of the high level of error detected.

Obviously there is a need for dramatic improvement. No doubt the Audit Office and the departments hope that the planned change for the administration of these schemes through the Health Insurance Commission will lead to some more effective way of dealing with this matter. It clearly needs that improvement to take place.

There are a couple of matters I want to raise on the question of fiddling the accounts at the end of the year. There is nothing new about fiddling accounts; it is just that it should not take place, particularly when it is in breach of the law. This, of course, is the simple fact. For example, there was a concern by the Audit Office relating to prepayments. There was a prepayment of $12.7m by the Department of Social Security to Telecom Australia which was made right at the end of the year in order to avoid that allocation not being spent. The Australian Audit Office questioned whether in fact this prepayment was effectively a form of investment, because it was to earn interest at some 15 per cent on the outstanding balance and therefore was outside the power of the Department to undertake.

The Audit Office also questioned whether the arrangements may have been made in order to avoid the lapsing of the appropriation and noted that additional estimates of some $11.5m sought in March 1989 would not have been needed without the prepayments. That is the interesting point for the Senate as we at present deal with Additional Estimates. Here we have the Department of Social Security asking for Additional Estimates of $11.5m, having in fact prepaid an account of something like $12.7m that was not due until the following financial year. It simply did not need the money in Supplementary Estimates and it fiddled the books to get this claim through this chamber and through our Estimates committees.

I find it absolutely vital that the Auditor-General has been able to tell us that we have been conned by the Department of Social Security but the big question is whether or not it is a sensible and proper thing to do because the Department signed the contract with Telecom for the prepayment of telephone accounts on 30 June 1989. The Audit Office naturally asked what less advantageous contractual arrangements would have occurred if payment had not been made until 1 July 1989.

There has been a lot of legal advice about this and, as I understand it, the Attorney-General says that there was no express requirement in the Appropriation Act that moneys paid relate to services rendered in the current year. But the wash-up of it all is that on 24 November 1989 the Department of Finance issued a revised Finance direction, 8d, which precludes an arrangement involving the early drawdown of cash if it would result in an adverse cash management outcome for the Commonwealth as a whole. The agreement with Telecom, the Auditor-General says, would not have met the requirements of this revised direction in that the rate of discount received by the Department from Telecom was less than the Commonwealth paid for its short-term borrowings during June of 1989.

That is only one instance shown here of this kind of fiddle. There is another one closer to home, once again within the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) of our own Parliament. It seems to be the popular whipping boy around here. We have an advance payment to consultants of $239,845. A payment of about a quarter of a million dollars was made in June 1989-is that not remarkable?-for the provision of consultancy services to the Department. The Audit Office found no evidence to support the explanations put forward by PISO through the Department that there were requirements for this advance payment to secure the services of key personnel. On the basis of the Audit finding, the Audit Office concluded that the prime motivation for the advance payment was to avoid the lapsing of the Department's appropriation, and the Department was therefore in breach of Finance direction 8d as it applied at the time.

Fiddling the books, when it is done in the private sector, is regarded as pretty naughty. I do not see why we should not regard this kind of fiddling the books, particularly when it involves the misleading of the Senate and of the parliamentary Estimates committees, as also quite improper.

There are also some problems pretty close to home relating to a cleaning contract in this building. In June 1988, the Joint House Department entered into a five-year contract for the cleaning of designated internal areas of the new Parliament House and encountered major difficulties with the operation of the contract almost from its inception. In response to Audit Office findings, the Department agreed that the certifying officer could not satisfy himself that the amount of $876,028-that is, an additional payment for cleaning here-claimed by the contractor over and above the fixed rate was correct. He could not satisfy himself that that payment was correct. The failure to ensure the correctness of payments is in breach of Finance regulation 45/1 (a). The Joint House Department also agreed that additional cleaning involving the payment of $433,153 was incurred without formal prior approval by an officer holding an appropriate delegation from the parliamentary Presiding Officers and that the cleaning of the car parks, road, basement and loading docks areas-that is, another $172,800 claimed-was allocated to the contractor without public tenders being called.

All these transactions breached Finance regulations. I must admit that it is probably difficult for us here to complain about what other departments are doing in terms of fiddling the books when we find that our own administration in this place is in fact breaching the requirements of the Parliament.

There is another curious situation in the Attorney-General's Department which shows how energetic and enthusiastic that Department is in fixing up mistakes. An account styled `Commonwealth investment equalisation account' had a balance of $381,615 at 30 June 1989 and had been inactive since 1985 when this amount was credited to the account, apparently in error. We have had $381,615 sitting in an account called `Commonwealth investment equalisation account' since 1985, when it was put there by error. Again I think we can expect better of our departments, and I am glad the Auditor-General has been able to discover this.

The Department has since been advised that the account has now been cleared by a transfer to revenue, but the matter was still under discussion with the Department at the date of preparation of this report. I would think it would be appropriate to have some pretty solid discussions with the Department on that sort of matter but, as I said, these issues are of some substance.

I now have only a couple more points that I want to make, and one of them relates to the granting of invalid pensions. The Auditor-General, I think, makes a very sound point when he says that he is of the view that the grounds on which an applicant may qualify for an invalid pension are not sufficiently clear and that an excessive degree of reliance is being placed on the discretion and judgment of departmental staff to make determinations which are in accordance with the legislative provisions and which would achieve consistency and fairness in outcome no matter at what regional office a person makes application for a pension or benefit. In other words, one can get an invalid pension by going to office No. A because the person there helping me has the capacity or desire, to grant one because of the discretion given. But one can go to office No. B and not get one, having exactly the same level of invalidity. I agree with the Auditor-General that that matter of great substance should be fixed.

The final point I want to make is that the Department of Finance is supposed to be the one that is, if you like, purer than pure. The Department of Finance is supposed to supervise these matters and make certain that proper accounting procedures continue. In the list at the back of this report there are 12 examples of breaches of Commonwealth law by the Department of Finance of its own requirements. For example, with respect to receipt books there was no evidence of independent monthly checks. One would hope that the Department of Finance might actually be able to get its act in order.

There is a lot of evidence of expenditure problems; overpayment of claims; and four breaches of Commonwealth law by the Department of Social Security. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade had numerous breaches as credits were offset against expenditure without the authority of the Minister for Finance. That is a simple way of boosting one's expenditure by slipping whatever revenue one has into one's expenditure accounts. There were numerous breaches by DEET where expenditure was not recorded on a functional basis as required by the Department of Finance. It is very pleasing to see a report which was received by the President only on 21 May, two days ago, tabled so promptly and available to the Senate for consideration. This report is a special and comprehensive review of the operations of the Squirrel training helicopters which are located at the Royal Australian Air Force Base, Fairbairn. These helicopters have been used primarily for the initial rotary wing flying training for Navy, Army and Air Force helicopter pilots.

The exercise by the Auditor-General was to assess the efficiency and effectiveness of the utilisation of these helicopters and their maintenance. The report made some important findings which I think should be brought to the attention of the Senate and studied by honourable senators. I do not propose to go into them in detail.

Broadly, the findings of the audit review were that considerable cost savings could be made by different methods of management and of the work practices in relation to the maintenance and utilisation of these helicopters. The report made a number of suggestions to the Department of Defence as to how they could be achieved. In fact, the Auditor-General has identified the possible savings of at least $2m per annum in relation to the management of these helicopters. One of the important recommendations is that by contracting out the maintenance functions to private industry there is a potential to make even further significant savings.

I am pleased to note that of the 31 recommendations made by the Australian Audit Office the Department of Defence has agreed in principle with virtually all the recommendations in one form or another. The exercise has been a valuable one. In view of the fact that so much agreement has been reached between the Audit Office and the Department of Defence we hope that there will be scope for these very considerable savings to be made. I think that is very important because the Opposition has been highly critical of the lack of adequate management practices and excessive overheads in this Department and believes that significant savings can be made if the Department looks carefully and in detail at its operations at central management level and at its management practices throughout the whole of the defence service.

The report highlights the savings that can be made and the importance of the contracting out of so many of the Department's functions. Obviously there has been far too great an adherence to the traditional methods of providing one's own in-house services. This is one particular and relatively small area-namely, the maintenance of this group of helicopters-where significant savings can be made as identified by the Audit Office. Greater readiness to contract out to private industries, as the Audit Office suggests, would result in significant savings and another method by which much better management could be installed in this large and important department. I believe that this report certainly deserves greater study, which I hope to be able to give it. I know that colleagues of mine also wish to study it further and comment on it.
